Is AoT the default build or JIT?
I see no difference in the build commands.

How to enable one or the other?

The default (using`npm build`) is a dev build, which is JIT.  For AoT, use `npm run build:aot`

From [README.MD](https://github.com/AngularClass/angular2-webpack-starter#build-files):

# development
npm run build:dev
# production (jit)
npm run build:prod
# AoT
npm run build:aot

Yes, in that regard they are the same.  The difference is that the :aot flag is parsed out in [webpack.common.js](https://github.com/AngularClass/angular2-webpack-starter/blob/master/config/webpack.common.js#L28) to determine if AoT should be performed or not.
Nice spot. What about the tsconfig.json?
It will always use `tsconfig.webpack.json`.  I'm guessing the repo includes a normal tsconfig so that IDEs like Visual Studio can compile the Typescript without affecting the Webpack build process.
Closing as the AOT identification is actually in the parameters detection

This version is **not covered** by your **current version range**. Without accepting this pull request your project will work just like it did before. There is a collection of [frequently asked questions](https://greenkeeper.io/faq.html) and while I’m just a bot, there is a group of people who are happy to teach me new things. [Let them know](https://github.com/greenkeeperio/greenkeeper/issues/new). Good luck with your project :sparkles: You rock! :palm_tree: --- [GitHub Release](https://github.com/webpack/webpack/releases/tag/v2.3.0)

Features:

  • add extensions option to DllReferencePlugin
  • add warningsFilter to UglifyJsPlugin to hide warnings selectively
  • add extractComments to UglifyJsPlugin to move kept comments into separate file (i. e. LICENSE file)
  • validate relative and absolute paths in configuration
  • validate stats options
  • allow to match on compiler (name in configuration) in rules
    • i. e. allows to specify different rules for extract-text-webpack-plugin or html-webpack-plugin
  • Allow to pass multiple entries via CLI
  • Performance improvements
  • CommonsChunkPlugin give errors on incorrect options
  • add module.strictExportPresence to make missing export an error instead of warning
  • Compiler emits watch-close event when the watcher is closed
  • Allow additional compress options in UglifyJsPlugin
  • empty chunk numbers are not flags in every chunk, this improves caching invalidation

Bugfixes:

  • OccurrenceOrderPlugin now counts occurrences correctly
  • Fix cheap-source-maps when combined with ES Modules (lines were offset)
  • Watcher now detects file deleting correctly
  • Resolve output path if relative output path is given via CLI
  • Handle stack traces in errors correctly
  • Some usages of System now generate valid code i. e. System.global
  • Dynamic property names are now parsed and can contain webpack stuff (i. e. imports)
  • Empty enviroment variables are now supported in the EnvironmentPlugin
  • (Maybe) Fixes chunk loading in IE when script is cached

@vincent-cm it is correct. The code is reported as broken by WebStorm because you have ECMAScript 5.1 (or another version) as your target version in Settings.

Go to `Settings -> Languages & Frameworks -> JavaScript`
Select `JavaScript language version` as `ECMAScript 6`

Re-open WebStorm, observe that errors gone.

Please close the issue, once you got it to work

* **I'm submitting a ...**
[ ] bug report
[ ] feature request
[ ] question about the decisions made in the repository

* **Do you want to request a *feature* or report a *bug*?**
bug


* **What is the current behavior?**
Getting an error below.

**Working Fine:**

routerConfig.unshift({
			path: 'detail',
			loadChildren: './+detail#DetailModule'
})

**Not working:**

let xxx = "./+detail#DetailModule";
routerConfig.unshift({
			path: 'detail',
			loadChildren: xxx 
})

Throwing the error below.

EXCEPTION: Uncaught (in promise): Error: Cannot find module './+detail'.
Error: Cannot find module './+detail'.

* **If the current behavior is a bug, please provide the steps to reproduce and if possible a minimal demo of the problem** via
https://plnkr.co or similar (you can use this template as a starting point: http://plnkr.co/edit/tpl:AvJOMERrnz94ekVua0u5).



* **What is the expected behavior?**

loadChildren should accept the variable and lazy module should work.


* **What is the motivation / use case for changing the behavior?**



* **Please tell us about your environment:**

- Angular version: 2.0.0-beta.X
- Browser: [all | Chrome XX | Firefox XX | IE XX | Safari XX | Mobile Chrome XX | Android X.X Web Browser | iOS XX Safari | iOS XX UIWebView | iOS XX WKWebView ]



* **Other information** (e.g. detailed explanation, stacktraces, related issues, suggestions how to fix, links for us to have context, eg. stackoverflow, gitter, etc)

This is most likely an issue with ng-router-loader, my guess is that it will not work since that loader looks at the router module file as a string so that it can find and replace the loadChildren property with  webpack friendly code. 

[if you look at this code](https://github.com/shlomiassaf/ng-router-loader/blob/master/src/builtin_codegens.ts) you can see what the loader replaces your config with so it works with webpack. i guess if you use this code snippet instead of the loader you can make it work as desired.

 `loadChildren: function() { return new Promise(function (resolve) {`,
    `  require.ensure([], function (require) {`,
    `    resolve(${requireString});`,
    `  }${webpackChunkName});`,
    `})}`


see docs here https://github.com/shlomiassaf/ng-router-loader

# Here the Readme File:

# angular2-webpack

[![Dependency Status](https://david-dm.org/preboot/angular2-webpack/status.svg)](https://david-dm.org/preboot/angular2-webpack#info=dependencies) [![devDependency Status](https://david-dm.org/preboot/angular2-webpack/dev-status.svg)](https://david-dm.org/preboot/angular2-webpack#info=devDependencies)
[![Join the chat at https://gitter.im/preboot/angular2-webpack](https://badges.gitter.im/preboot/angular2-webpack.svg)](https://gitter.im/preboot/angular2-webpack?utm_source=badge&utm_medium=badge&utm_campaign=pr-badge&utm_content=badge)

**Note: This guide is following the Angular's [Style Guide](http://angular.io/styleguide) so I will be changing conventions here and there eventually. You are free to use your own conventions with this starter.**
**Note 2: There is no conventions yet for RC5 on the style guide so there will be a future update here for that.**

A complete, yet simple, starter for Angular 2 using Webpack.

This seed repo serves as an Angular 2 starter for anyone looking to get up and running with Angular 2 and TypeScript fast. Using [Webpack](http://webpack.github.io/) for building our files and assisting with boilerplate. We're also using Protractor for our end-to-end story and Karma for our unit tests.
* Best practices in file and application organization for [Angular 2](https://angular.io/).
* Ready to go build system using [Webpack](https://webpack.github.io/docs/) for working with [TypeScript](http://www.typescriptlang.org/).
* Testing Angular 2 code with [Jasmine](http://jasmine.github.io/) and [Karma](http://karma-runner.github.io/).
* Coverage with [Istanbul](https://github.com/gotwarlost/istanbul)
* End-to-end Angular 2 code using [Protractor](https://angular.github.io/protractor/).
* Stylesheets with [SASS](http://sass-lang.com/) (not required, it supports regular css too).
* Error reported with [TSLint](http://palantir.github.io/tslint/) and [Codelyzer](https://github.com/mgechev/codelyzer).
* Documentation with [TypeDoc](http://typedoc.io/).

>Warning: Make sure you're using the latest version of Node.js and NPM

[Is Angular 2 Ready Yet?](http://splintercode.github.io/is-angular-2-ready/)

### Quick start

> Clone/Download the repo then edit `app.ts` inside [`/src/app/app.component.ts`](/src/app/app.component.ts)

<S_CODE_TOKEN>
go to [http://localhost:8080](http://localhost:8080) in your browser.

# Table of Contents

* [Getting Started](#getting-started)

# Getting Started

## Dependencies

What you need to run this app:
* `node` and `npm` (Use [NVM](https://github.com/creationix/nvm))
* Ensure you're running Node (`v5.x.x`+) and NPM (`3.x.x`+)

## Installing

* `fork` this repo
* `clone` your fork
* `npm install` to install all dependencies

## Developing

After you have installed all dependencies you can now start developing with:

* `npm start`

It will start a local server using `webpack-dev-server` which will watch, build (in-memory), and reload for you. The application can be checked at `http://localhost:8080`.

As an alternative, you can work using Hot Module Replacement (HMR):

* `npm run start:hmr`

And you are all set! You can now modify your components on the fly without having to reload the entire page.

## Testing

#### 1. Unit Tests

* single run: `npm test`
* live mode (TDD style): `npm run test-watch`

#### 2. End-to-End Tests (aka. e2e, integration)

* single run:
  * in a tab, *if not already running!*: `npm start`
  * in a new tab: `npm run webdriver-start`
  * in another new tab: `npm run e2e`
* interactive mode:
  * instead of the last command above, you can run: `npm run e2e-live`
  * when debugging or first writing test suites, you may find it helpful to try out Protractor commands without starting up the entire test suite. You can do this with the element explorer.
  * you can learn more about [Protractor Interactive Mode here](https://github.com/angular/protractor/blob/master/docs/debugging.md#testing-out-protractor-interactively)

## Production

To build your application, run:

* `npm run build`

You can now go to `/dist` and deploy that to your server!

## Documentation

You can generate api docs (using [TypeDoc](http://typedoc.io/)) for your code with the following:

* `npm run docs`

# FAQ

#### Do I need to add script / link tags into index.html ?

No, Webpack will add all the needed Javascript bundles as script tags and all the CSS files as link tags. The advantage is that you don't need to modify the index.html every time you build your solution to update the hashes.

#### How to include external angular 2 libraries ?

It's simple, just install the lib via npm and import it in your code when you need it. Don't forget that you need to configure some external libs in the [bootstrap](https://github.com/preboot/angular2-webpack/blob/master/src/main.ts) of your application.

#### How to include external css files such as bootstrap.css ?

Just install the lib and import the css files in [vendor.ts](https://github.com/preboot/angular2-webpack/blob/master/src/vendor.ts). For example this is how to do it with bootstrap:

# TypeScript

> To take full advantage of TypeScript with autocomplete you would have to use an editor with the correct TypeScript plugins.

## Use a TypeScript-aware editor

We have good experience using these editors:

* [Visual Studio Code](https://code.visualstudio.com/)
* [Webstorm 11+](https://www.jetbrains.com/webstorm/download/)
* [Atom](https://atom.io/) with [TypeScript plugin](https://atom.io/packages/atom-typescript)
* [Sublime Text](http://www.sublimetext.com/3) with [Typescript-Sublime-Plugin](https://github.com/Microsoft/Typescript-Sublime-plugin#installation)

Starting from a pristine install, I had to make a couple of modifications before I was able to successfully build and serve for production. 

------------

First, I noticed that `webpack-dev-server.js` was being included in `index.html` regardless of NODE_ENV. 

To fix this, I changed:

`src/index.html` L56
from `<% if (webpackConfig.metadata.ENV === 'development') { %>`
to      `<% if (process.env.ENV === 'development') { %>`

---------------

Next, I was having trouble getting my styles included with an `EXCEPTION: Failed to load %5Bobject%20Object%5D` error as seen in [this SO question](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/38102760/getting-failed-to-load-5bobject20object5d-on-webpack-generated-js-hosted-in-e)

For this, I changed:

`src/app/app.component.ts` L47
from `styleUrls: [require('!style!css!sass!../sass/main.scss')],`
to `styles: String[require('!style!css!sass!../sass/main.scss')],`

- Browser: [all /Chrome/Firefox ]

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

Don't know if it was just for me, but following "How to use Bootstrap 3 and Sass and ng2 bootstrap" wiki page caused bootstrap glyphicon to not load on aot production build.

Managed to fix my issue by including 
$icon-font-path: '~bootstrap-sass/assets/fonts/bootstrap/';
@import '~bootstrap-sass/assets/stylesheets/bootstrap';

to 'src/styles/style.scss' instead of 'src/app/app.component.scss' as wiki suggest.

Thought I share my experience if anyone comes into the same issue.

I have just done a not so scientific comparison between npm run start:hmr and npm start.  I am just changing some html.  hmr takes 3 to 4 seconds to reload.  non-hmr, takes maybe 4.5 seconds.  Is 3 to 4 seconds the fastest speed hmr can go? (I have a pretty fast and modern laptop)

You won't notice an appreciable difference with HMR until you work with a larger project.

I have an app with 50+ components split into several lazy loaded modules.  A regular build takes 90 seconds, while an HMR compile/reload takes around 10 seconds.
OK. hopefully the fastest speed can be improved in the future.

This is minor issue, but you may find it important to track it. The docs importing external css https://github.com/AngularClass/angular2-webpack-starter#external-stylesheets should change "@import 'bootstrap/scss/bootstrap.scss';" to "@import '~bootstrap/scss/bootstrap.scss';". It does not compile without this ~ mark, at least for leaflet.css dependency.

Regards,
Andrey

This works, but there seems to be a pathing issue with a separate CSS library, font-awesome, when it tries to find the **fonts** folder.

**EDIT (Temporary solution)**: This is a hack, but to get FA to work, here's what I did:

1. `npm i -D copyfiles`
2. Added npm script: `"copy:fa:fonts": "copyfiles -f node_modules/font-awesome/fonts/* src/fonts",`
3. `npm run copy:fa:fonts`

I dislike doing this because it defies the project's directory structure and practices... having **fonts** outside of **styles** and font-awesome not being able to resolve its fonts like bootstrap does.

I'm trying to include a 3rd party javascript library that also has CSS... I too wasn't wanting to copy the CSS from the node_modules folder. At least now I can see a way of doing it "simply" via a command, but I think there should be some documentation on using third party libraries that also need CSS.

@daominhsangvn The extract text plugin is trying to load (and extract) the css from that package, which is defined at the component level.

My suggestion is to block the extract plugin from running when styles are coming from node_modules

@daominhsangvn you use angular2-perfect-scrollbar this is the same that i use. 

When i check out the lastest starter and add this module it works without errors.

@derdiggn : I'm using that Plugin btw, did you try build AoT yet?
Using that plugin in development and production is fine.
@shlomiassaf Thanks, that's a good point to start with.

ok Thanks @shlomiassaf for the point. I resolved this issue by exclude the angular2-perfect-scrollbar from ExtractTextPlugin and use css-loader combine with to-string-loader for angular2-perfect-scrollbar.

I'm not sure why the ExtractTextPlugin cannot find the css file of angular2-perfect-scrollbar but this is just work around.

Anyway, problem solved. Closed!

Hi Guys

I am creating a shared library using this library but a I found that when services are left out by the TreeShaking since there are not used neither imported or declared on my ngModule.

How Can I exclude a folder from the treeShaking code.

Best Regards

This repository is not intended for library creation.

Webpack can only create UMD bundles but angualr2 libraries require ESM modules as well, for AOT compilation.

This is done by TS and the angular compiler-cli

See [this](https://github.com/shlomiassaf/ngc-webpack/issues/7#issuecomment-279292758) for more detailed explanation.

Thanks @shlomiassaf 
I just found this out today in a post on StackOverflow:

> Note: As of Angular CLI 1.0.0-beta.28 (released February 1st, 2017), --aot is on by default if --prod is specified.

Using `npm run build:aot:prod`, and stripping out some stuff from this starter project to make it comparable to a normal clean angular project, actually produced a smaller vendor file: 312KB with this vs 352KB

* **What is the current behavior?**

I can't send a PR upgrading angular to version 2.4.7 because travis fails with node < 6.9.5

* **What is the motivation / use case for changing the behavior?**

Angular 2.4.7  and Protractor 5.0.0 requires node >= 6.9.5

* **What kind of change does this PR introduce?** (Bug fix, feature, docs update, ...)
Run clean task at the time for build both for dev and production.


* **What is the current behavior?** (You can also link to an open issue here)
While running `build` task, it does not remove `compiled` directory which consist of Angular`s ngFactory files. Which through compile error even while building for development environment.
It is always good to freshly install dependencies on production to avoid such issues.

![error](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2920003/22930266/69854948-f2e5-11e6-9c25-0a56e074cc4f.png)



* **What is the new behavior (if this is a feature change)?**
It will freshly install all the dependencies and create `dll` and `compile` files. Which avoids unexpected error during build time.


* **Other information**:
Now when you run `npm run build` or `npm run build:aot`

1. Clean task will run which will remove `node_modules doc coverage dist compiled dll`.
2. And `npm install` will run which will install all the dependencies and pass webpack config for build.

* **What kind of change does this PR introduce?** (Bug fix, feature, docs update, ...)

Ficx and update dependencies to last versions.

* **What is the current behavior?** (You can also link to an open issue here)

Versions are not fixed so could be slight differences between each `npm install`.

* **What is the new behavior (if this is a feature change)?**

Dependencies fixed and updated to last versions.

* **Other information**:

* **What kind of change does this PR introduce?** (Bug fix, feature, docs update, ...)

feature

* **What is the current behavior?** (You can also link to an open issue here)

AppComponent selector is ``app``

* **What is the new behavior (if this is a feature change)?**

AppComponent selector is ``my-app``


* **Other information**:

Uses a hyphenated, lowercase element selector value. Follows [Angular styleguide](https://angular.io/styleguide#!#02-07). Is a [valid custom element name](https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/scripting.html#valid-custom-element-name). Solves [HTML validation error](https://validator.w3.org/nu/): "Element app not allowed as child of element div in this context. (Suppressing further errors from this subtree.)".
Sorry, but I close this PR. This depends upon taste, and the settings of your tslint.

Hi,

Latest repo version, running `npm run build:aot:prod`:  
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5377501/22889574/4f6bb778-f212-11e6-90a6-f545aeb17416.png)

**Total folder size: 1M**

Latest repo version, running `npm run build:prod`:  
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5377501/22889593/5b9cfeee-f212-11e6-98e6-4c7216014768.png)

**Total folder size: 1.3M**

You might notice that the `main` file and `chunk` files are larger in `build:prod:aot` then in `build:prod`, this is perfectly normal since AOT produces more code.

The total amount is less in AOT since the compiler is not part of the bundle, you can see it in the size of the `vendor` bundle.

This also means that as your application grow, AOT will yield larger code since you add more AOT generated code but the compiler size is constant.

The angular team is working on reducing the emitted code, one of the upcoming feature for this is a new [View Engine](https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/14013) that will reduce bundle size but will slightly effect performance (it's always a tradeoff)

I see no issue here, try to start from scratch, you probably changed something

* **What kind of change does this PR introduce?** (Bug fix, feature, docs update, ...)

Feature about the Webpack configuration

* **What is the current behavior?** (You can also link to an open issue here)

The Webpack configuration it's called individually for all the run. This is somehow explicit about the configuration, but it is not good for extends. 

* **What is the new behavior (if this is a feature change)?**

This PR should introduce a new structure for the Webpack configuration folders. This should be easy to understand, and to extend. The webpack should be called without any config argument, and the main Webpack config file should call the Webpack config folder. This `index.js` should be able to resolve the request configuration and return it. 

* **Other information**:

  - It should work now for common browsers build. 
  - Github deploy still WIP. 
  - This code needs Node 6 to run (Destructive imports, parameters initialization). But as it's being discussed here (#1368) Node 5 it's not supported by Angular 2, so, effectively this doesn't support anything below Node 6 LTS either.

Ya i was using in a template and i oversaw it as i have two systems and the code wasn't refractored. Thanks a lot , now it works fine . Closing the issue

* **What kind of change does this PR introduce?** (Bug fix, feature, docs update, ...)

As per `extract-text-webpack-plugin` version [2.0.0-rc.3](https://github.com/webpack-contrib/extract-text-webpack-plugin/releases/tag/v2.0.0-rc.3) following are deprecated.

- `fallbackLoader` is replaced with `fallback`
- `loader` is replaced with `use`

You will get following message on console while building for production `npm run build:aot:prod` 

![msg](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2920003/22737081/7879c428-ee27-11e6-8d2f-1ff2ad04c8cc.png)

* **Other information**:
We don't need `path` module as it is done using `helpers.root`. see [this](https://github.com/AngularClass/angular2-webpack-starter/commit/1ea8b71fe2bc1debe608eb604cb18b35ddda8884)

NO_COVERAGE is provide for IDE integration

This PR enables proper breaking point in TS code.

Fixes #1392

Approach:
All configurations files (karma/webpack.test) are configured without coverage, if coverage support is needed it will be added into the config's.
This is common sense, there's no point in setting something then removing it which is also not clear and readable.

Coverage is opt-out, i.e. by default you will get coverage reports... the developer needs to opt out of coverage explicitly.

There are 2 ways to opt out:
  - Using `--watch-mode`. watch mode implies development session so no coverage there. This is automatically set as part of the npm scripts in this project.

  - Using `NO_COVERAGE` environment variable, when set the coverage will not run. This is a fallback that is useful for IDE integration where karama is executed and controlled by the IDE.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5377501/22733664/72be0e8a-edfb-11e6-9475-efdaa3ca91d7.png)

Can you open it in the [optimize-js](https://github.com/nolanlawson/optimize-js)

If I just clone the repo it doesn't happen...
This does not happen with the repo on its own. It will start to happen if we use it in a project, and the project grows to a certain degree. Note: **npm run build:prod** runs ok.
Is there a way to increase the maximum RAM for npm before run build:aot:prod?
`node --max_old_space_size=4096`

How do we run it with the npm command? 
node --max_old_space_size=4096 npm run build:aot:prod?

So I added this script to the package.json file 
`"myscript": "npm run build:aot:prod && node --max_old_space_size=4096"`
and ran it like this
`npm run myscript`

But without luck still getting the heap out of memory error.

@pilgylis did you find a solution to this?

Tried various ways without any luck :(

How about splitting the aot build into multiple steps, for example, the first step is to generate the compile folder, and the second is to merge it?

I noticed that when the out of memory occured, the compile folder had been created. Can someone helps to create a command to continue from that?

Finally made it work!!
check out: https://github.com/AngularClass/angular2-webpack-starter/pull/1491/files

Also I had to made the following changes in order to work on my machine:

`"webpack-dev-server": "node --max_old_space_size=4096 node_modules/webpack-dev-server/bin/webpack-dev-server.js",
        "webpack": "node --max_old_space_size=4096 node_modules/webpack/bin/webpack.js"`

My explanation (mostly guess) is follow. Please correct me if anything is incorrect.

'npm' is in fact the shortcut for 'node npm-cli.js'. Basically when we run 'node something.js', the content of something.js will be put into a js function (with environmental parameters) and run.

In our case, 'webpack' and 'webpack.cmd' are in fact OS batch files, so when put into a js function, it is obviously an error; and 'node webpack.js' works.

Note: I am using Node 7.5

I'm just thinking if there would be some better way to pass the memory limit parameter than calling node directly from package.json (for example in some debian based machines doesn't have `node` executable but its called `nodejs` so there is a little crossplatform compatibility issue in there too...).

I'm not sure if I understood correctly what you meant with the comment how `npm` runs the scripts declared in package.json, but I'm sure it doesn't wrap those scripts to any js function, but just directly executes them in a new process with some additional environment variables given. I haven't checked the code, but I suppose it just calls `spawn` or `exec` to run them.

[This file](https://github.com/AngularClass/angular2-webpack-starter/blob/master/src/main.browser.aot.ts) should not really be in this project. The problem is that it's depend on `AppModuleNgFactory` which is imported `from "../compiled/src/app/AppModule.ngfactory";`. But this file is not present in the project until you compile it using ngc. And even if you compile it, what to do with other people having this error? They can run same command, but this is not an option. Another option is to commit these files, but its also bad idea. Having always the error that this file is missing absolutely not an option.

AFAIK angular-cli does not require you to create this file and handles aot specifics by its own.

@pleerock This file belongs to the project, no issue with it.

`angular-cli` creates this file at webpack runtime, but in the same time has a lot of other "enforcements", like having to use it's internal TS loader and other stuff.

There is no issue with this file in the project since it is not an entry point when not in AOT mode hence it's there but not used.

When this file is used, it is in AOT mode which means that the AOT compiler just finished running so the file is referencing an existing file.

The error people get is because the `awesome-typescript-loader` type checker does not care about the entry point, it parses the whole library so people get errors but they are virtual.

The error should be fixed soon once s-panferov/awesome-typescript-loader#364 is set which is the direct cause of the problem

See #1378
I've never gotten an error related to this anyway using recent versions of this repo.
@colinskow run typescript compiler without webpack and you'll get it.
@pleerock that's because the tsconfig is not configured for that task.

@shlomiassaf , no, it is configured. I'm talking about using typescript compiler without anything else (webpack, ngc, etc.). There are nothing in tsconfig that indicates to skip `main.browser.aot.ts` file (solution may be to exclude `main.browser.aot.ts` from default tsc compilation). Checkout this repo from scratch, don't use webpack or ngc, just use tsc and you'll see typescript compiler error.

@pleerock I'm not saying the running `tsc` as you describe will not yield an error, it will.

When I say 
>  that's because the tsconfig is not configured for that task.

I mean that the way you use it is not the way it is intended to be used.

`tsc` is a command line tool based on a static JSON file, if you want multiple configurations you need multiple files.

This repository is based on webpack, not `tsc`, we use webpack tools to dynamically control the tool chain. We don't exclude `main.browser.aot.ts` in our **tsconfig** because we relay on webpack **entryPoint** for that.

You are trying to use one of the tools in the toolchain without providing the proper environment to it, which we do using webpack.

Anyway, I can't think of any use case to run `tsc` outside of webpack, the output will not work even if no error.

> Anyway, I can't think of any use case to run tsc outside of webpack, the output will not work even if no error.

actually it will depend on use case if you configure it properly.

The problem is IDE compiler. IDE uses tsc to compile the code and it does not care about webpack. You'll have this error in IDE until you run webpack which will run ngc which will create "compile" directory with file required for compilation. Bad workflow.
Which exact command I should execute to get `/compiled/` directory in project? When I execute `npm run build:aot` it doesn't create any new folders.

I think some refactor should be done too:

# Rename webpack.*.ts files

Webpack should have 3 config files:

1. webpack.dev.js: development mode: no minimize files, create sourcemap...)
2. webpack.test.js: for unit testing
3. webpack.build.js: build aot or jit

The file webpack.common.js should be renamed too because it's not used in webpack.dev.js. It could be webpack.helpes.js or webpack.utils.js and it should have functions that could be used in the other config files to inject some plugin, config or whatever.

# Create real eviroment config files

The project should have different enviroment config files:

* config.dev.js
* config.pre.js
* config.pro.js
* config.github.js

In these files the user could set the API URL, the domain used, the color of the topbar or what they want.

DefinePlugin should add these config to use in .ts files. Something like:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

# Create config.ts file

And the project should have one config.ts file. The user should not use `process.env`. A config.ts file that could be:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

I like your suggest about the management of the ENV variable. However, I think instead of using `process.env` it would be better to use Webpack own `env` variable. It's setteable alike, and I think it's better to understand. Also, you would not need to parse anything, cause Webpack can handle that itself. 

My current workflow works with the `env` variable. 

`Webpack folders` 
![captura de pantalla 74](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10507776/22648076/336abe42-ec4b-11e6-901f-76211aedea02.png)

![captura de pantalla 75](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10507776/22648077/37c63a2a-ec4b-11e6-8d81-b4c834977550.png)

An structure like this, would also have some benefits over current implementation. See this function for example:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

If the production flag, it's set in the env, or even using npm config scripts, it would just be requesting to `webpack/browser`, and it would resolve itself to the most apropiarte config regardless the request.

  • options.port now allows strings to be passed in, previously only integers were accepted (#766).

Hi,

I do have Polymer elements working fine.

1. create a main-polymer.ts that contains: document.addEventListener('WebComponentsReady', () => {require('./main.browser.ts')});
2. your webpack.config.ts or webpack.common.ts may then contain:    entry: {

      'polyfills': './src/polyfills.browser.ts',
      'vendor':    './src/vendor.browser.ts',
      'main':      './src/main-polymer.ts'
    },

That's it.
Then you're sure that your polymer elements are loaded and working before your app get loaded.
I hop that's what you where looking for.

The JIT compiler is not present when you compile AOT, that's what compiling AOT means otherwise it was JIT, right?

JIT compiler is not included in the bundle when you AOT compile, in your case you included it since you created a hard reference but it was not properly set, you can't just use it you need to hook it up with angular, when you AOT compile its not hooked, when you JIT compile it is automatically hooked by angular.

if you want to do JIT compilation with AOT you need to instantiate the JIT compiler through DI (providers) 

This is how to do it with lazy loading the JIT compiler in a different lazy-loaded NgModule.
https://github.com/shlomiassaf/lazy-jit

The JIT compiler is quite big so this is why you will want it to lazy load.
On of the main reasons for AOT is not bundling the JIT compiler, its 60% of angular.

Everything you need is in the referenced repository, other then that it's a support issue which we kindly ask to forward to the relevant forums.

@shlomiassaf 
Thanks for your fast answer and your good job.
Problem was with NgcWebpackPlugin in default webpack.common.js:
<S_CODE_TOKEN>
After removing 'resourceOverride' dynamic creating work good with AOT compiling even with JitCompilerFactory.

As we understood this option do not remove from components source of HTML templates and JIT compiler can read and compile these templates.

So repeat. How is actually it works:
1. If components was compiled by AOT.
2. Some dynamic component wants to use one or more AOT components.
3. Shall JIT compiler recompile all component (templates, styles) used by dynamic component?
It means that we shall save all source html and styles after AOT compilation for JIT compiler.
Also we shall include JIT compiler to our project.
As result we will have: additional size of JIT compiler + all sources of components. 

Thanks a lot.

I am currently having the same issue with this setup

This error is fired by the `CheckerPlugin` from `awesome-typescript-loader`

The checker plugin process all typescript files in the `src` directory while the `awesome-typescript-loader` process files that webpack provides starting from the root (entryPoint).

The end result is `src/main.browser.aot.ts` being process by the `CheckerPlugin` and if there is no content in the compile directory there is an error.

This is why we get a type error but not a bundling error, this is a "virtual" error that does not effect the end result, runtime will have no error.

The workaround is not a viable solution, the `tsconfig.json` is for the test environment and it will require syncing up both configs every time, if we need some changes to the test environment (and only test) we will face an issue.

There is a [PR proposal](https://github.com/AngularClass/angular2-webpack-starter/pull/1378) that tried to make typescript config dynamic but it makes things a bit more complicated for the end developer.

The best solution is typescript to accepts commonJS modules instead of json file :)

Ok, I see. Looks like we're going with yet another ``tsconfig.*.json`` file that is going to be used for non-AoT builds ... maybe ``tsconfig.dev.json`` or ``tsconfig.jit.json`` ... do you think this is a useful thing to have in this starter repo?
@dherges not sure if there will be another file, see s-panferov/awesome-typescript-loader#364

@shlomiassaf I don't get it. Right now, we have two files in this repo:

``tsconfig.json`` for tests
``tsconfig.webpack.json`` for webpack build

my suggestion is to add another one:

``tsconfig.jit.json`` for JiT compiler builds

plus, we could rename ``tsconfig.webpack.json`` to ``tsconfig.aot.json`` to make it clear, that this one is used for AoT compiler builds.

Did you look at s-panferov/awesome-typescript-loader#364

Instead of complicating the build with another static JSON configuration file that issue offers dynamic control over the scope of the checker.

Now, it might seem simple enough to add another `tsconfig.jit.json` but the reality is that someone has to maintain it...

Every change made in one `tsconfig.XXX.json`has to be replicated into all other tsconfig files.

We already have hard time dealing with the different TEST environment setup and once in a while we discover that a feature that was added to one config was not added to another....

Not to mention we have multiple webpack configs and multiple tsconfig configs.

The goal is to consolidate the configuration and not spread it, so I don't think adding a new file is the right approach.

Again, s-panferov/awesome-typescript-loader#364 offers a good solution, a little patience and we will fix this.

Of course, I'm not calling the shots, so please lets get input from @d3viant0ne @gdi2290 @colinskow

Thanks for your clarification. I understand your points.

At the same time, I like to see the resulting configuration. Having "plain" json files in the repository allows to quickly compare different tsconfigs. I fully agree that this spreads out configuration and makes it harder to maintain.

So, from my point of view, this is about maintainability vs. debuggability (does that word even exist?!?!): with dynamic config, I'd like to have some utility that prints the configuration. Maybe, I should reach out to s-panferov/awesome-typescript-loader then 💯

@dherges The tradeoff is clear, the balance is not.

The current status is that:
  - AOT compilation in angular is not that trivial, lot's of factors people don't realise.
  - Running unit tests with Karma requires a completely unique configuration
 
Add to that HMR, unique loaders, special production settings, linting etc.. 
The end result is a complicated process, to complicated if you ask me.

I help a lot of friends with setups, its a real blocker for most and this is why the angular-cli is a must, and I hope it will allow the freedom we get here, one day.

To sum up, factoring all of the above I think we should avoid spreading as much as possible.

This is also fixed by #1378, but s-panferov/awesome-typescript-loader#364 will provide a better solution. We should wait to avoid over-complicating things.

And cloning the latest version of this repository on Mac and Windows I am able to do `npm run build:prod` just fine without any errors.

**I'm submitting a ...**
[x] feature request


**What is the current behavior?**
For now, the angular app refreshes every time a .scss or .css file is changed


**What is the expected behavior?**
Ideally, styles files are recompiled and inject into page without refreshing the page 


**What is the motivation / use case for changing the behavior?**
Because for now, every page fresh takes me at least **5 seconds**, and gets longer as the app grows. 

I am writing a lot of scss styles for my angular2 app, I used to use GulpJS, which inject the new compiled css into the page in real time, done in **1 second** (There's no page refreshes). However for now I have to wait for at least **5 seconds** (page refreshes) every time I save my scss files.


**Please tell us about your environment:**

- Angular version: ^2.4.5
- Browser: [Chrome 55.0.2883.95 (64-bit)]
This is the major downside of Webpack comparing to well-created Gulpfile.js : it is much slower even if it does all its manipulation in memory. After even a tiny change it has to rebuild the bundle.

@zhekaus exactly!

There seems to be ways to do css HMR without refreshing page, I googled online, tried some solutions, not work, so I wonder if AngularClass team has any ideas on this.

@zhekaus @gudh it depends how you structure your app.

when you used Gulp I imagine you didn't do it on Angular 2 right? so instead of blaming webpack try to understand the environment :)

CSS in angular `@Component`s are not part of the global CSS you used to have in Gulp and that was loaded via a HTML link tag.

CSS that you attach to components is part of the bundle, if you refresh CSS the whole ngModule must refresh.

It is possible that the reloading can improve, but it will take time once people fully realise the process and webpack will adapt.

@shlomiassaf, could we use ExtractTextPlugin to bundle all of the Component css as a separate css bundle loaded via link tag? Aside from one less network request, is there a benefit to having it all be part of the main js bundle? Or at least, could this be done for Dev builds to benefit from faster CSS reloads?

Typescript 2.1 has a new option called `importHelpers` that allows use `noEmitHelpers` without `ts-helpers`.

In [ts-helpers wiki](https://github.com/ngParty/ts-helpers):

> NOTE: Starting Typescript 2.1 this package won't be needed anymore

More info:

* https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/pull/9097
* https://github.com/Microsoft/tslib

With this change we can use `extends` in protractor ts files for e2e tests.

If you don't want do this change, you should add `require('ts-helpers');` at the beginning of the file `protractor.conf.js`.

* **What kind of change does this PR introduce?** (Bug fix, feature, docs update, ...)
refactor

* **What is the current behavior?** (You can also link to an open issue here)
Some places reference root without using `helpers.root()`


* **What is the new behavior (if this is a feature change)?**
Adding `helpers.root()` so references are consistent


* **Other information**:
We use this starter as the base for an internally-published build system so we can have a little more control over how/when we pull updates into many different projects. Consistent use of helpers.root makes it easier to package this.

For the following directory structure:

    ..src/frontend/...
    ..src/frontend/src/...
    ..src/frontend/config/webpack.common.js
    ..src/shared/src/models/User.ts

I've got my Typescript setup using [rootDirs][1]. This is quite handy because I can have a shared folder for front- and back-end.

This allows me to rewrite an long ugly import statement

    import {User} from "../../../shared/src/models/User";

to this 

    import {User} from "../models/User";

This works well and my TypeScript service is happy and able to resolve all modules etc. The problem comes in with Webpack.

It doesn't seem to look at the tsconfig file for module resolution. So going to the [Webpack 2 documentation][2]. I found the following for resolve.modules.

> Tell webpack what directories should be searched when resolving
> modules.
> 
> Absolute and relative paths can both be used, but be aware that they
> will behave a bit differently.

I have tried configuring the modules :

     modules: [helpers.root('src'), helpers.root('node_modules') , helpers.root( '../shared/src')]

This allows me to use an import statement: 

     import {User} from "models/User"; //Note the missing ../

But now TypeScript doesn't know what type it is any longer, since it breaks away from the rootDirs config. Ideally I would want Webpack and Typescript to be in sync. If I use the long relative import path then webpack and typescript are both happy.

See my [gist][3] of my config files.

Error I get when using '../models/User'

> ERROR in ./src/app/environment.ts Module not found: Error: Can't
> resolve '../models/User' in
> '/home/tersiusk/WebstormProjects/pinkdot2/src/frontend/src/app'  @
> ./src/app/environment.ts 4:0-38  @ ./src/main.browser.ts



  [1]: https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/module-resolution.html#virtual-directories-with-rootdirs
  [2]: https://webpack.js.org/configuration/resolve/#resolve-modules
  [3]: https://gist.github.com/ktersius/4deaa6dc55b4bdd22b5f3dc933b77b33

* **What kind of change does this PR introduce?** (Bug fix, feature, docs update, ...)
Feature/refactor

* **What is the current behavior?** (You can also link to an open issue here)
Both dev and prod builds build to a single 'dist' folder so it is not easy to build both and compare side by side. Additionally, when cleaning the project, this folder is removed which can be a problem in IDEs when trying to permanently exclude the folder from the project.

* **What is the new behavior (if this is a feature change)?**
Builds are placed under a single "build" folder. This allows dev, prod, and aot builds to coexist. It also allows more targeted cleaning.

* **Other information**:

* **What kind of change does this PR introduce?** (Bug fix, feature, docs update, ...)
Move application config from a random area in the config folder to the package.json file.


* **What is the current behavior?** (You can also link to an open issue here)
Title is hardcoded in the config folder


* **What is the new behavior (if this is a feature change)?**
Title configuration has been moved to package.json


* **Other information**:
I found this particularly useful because I also used a bootstrap header bar with the title, and having it in two places was particularly annoying, so this was a good maintainability change for me.

I would prefer to have project-specific config pulled out and merged in via separate configs. App title is just one example, but there are other things like the DLL config which don't make sense to add to package.json. Separate project config would cover all cases. 

I know this adds to complexity a bit, but it makes it easier to pull updates from this starter into existing projects.

Maybe, but I generally prefer to not have too many config files. A separate application block in package.json generally suffices for me. That said, this is pretty subjective. If it's not generally applicable enough it could be closed, but I still think any config-related data (not to be confused with the bootstrapping stuff in `config/`) should be pulled out.

Problem with an application block in package.json is that it complicates things when dealing with something other than strings. For instance, configuring loaders or plugins. If we did separate project configs, they could be very simple by default so as to not unnecessarily complicate/confuse things. Optional config if you need it, but otherwise you could use the starter as-is.

Its because of extra commas needed, thats why I was using pug-plugin-ng
are you sure you tried on a clean install? It looks like some actual pug compilation bug

pug-loader returns a function, on imports you must call that function, ie
`template: require('./template.pug')();'`

You must take in consideration that you need to write some angular expressions with '' take this snippet of code for example. 

`md-card('(click)'= 'functionCall(data.param)')`
if the call to (click) and the call to the function are not in '', app will break. 
This is exactly what I've been trying to avoid, using pug-plugin-ng + pug-html-loader https://www.npmjs.com/package/pug-plugin-ng

Actually you only need to provide the `templateUrl` with a string, `angular-template-loader` or whatever it's called transforms it into a `require` call and `apply-loader` calls the function.
And regarding the template you can simply write `md-card( (click)="functionCall(data.param)", [attr.something]="something?.else" )`

Okay found the problem,  My import on the new file was wrong, instead of 
`import {TestBed} from "@angular/core/testing";`  (A)
I did'
`import {TestBed, inject, async} from "@angular/core/testing/test_bed";` (B)

I think that way I imported a testbed (B) which was not attached to any environment - but I couldn't intialize an environment for it because it was already intialized for TestBed (A) in spec-bundle.

After that I changed (B) to (A). 
Can't believe I've let auto import hit me like that.

I'm closing the issue and hopefully it will help someone in the future, sorry for bothering.

After using SASS in project, it's seem very essential to sharing `_variables.scss` in all SASS files, instead manually import it each time, which can be over head especially when styling Angular Components thats may locating deep in the project directories so the relative path to `_variables.scss` can be very long. I can live with that... but most devs won't know about it so they will just add `@imports` to the `_variable` file... we'll end up supporting sass resource loader.

Ah, I was referencing my fonts with a relative path. If I change that reference to `/assets/fonts/...`, I no longer need to add url-loader and everything works by simply referencing copied fonts under `/assets/fonts/`. 

Would be curious to hear an explanation for this as I don't quite understand what's going on here, but this issue can be closed otherwise.
Completely valid usability issue, one of us will take a look at it this evening

A little more insight into this. The solution I described above only works because root-relative paths cause css-loader to skip hashing those assets by default. So, for example, if I add `?root=/.` to css-loader, this causes it to process root-relative the paths and the css will be changed to point to `[hash].ttf`. Plain prod builds work as expected here: the fonts are copied with hashed filenames and the css is updated to point to them. However, in AOT builds, while the css is updated, the actual hashed files are not being generated.
Looks like the same issue here #1428

@bmayen the issue in #1428 happens on non-inlined assets within component templates/styles.

Are you loading fonts in component styles? bit excessive... if so turn `resourceOverride` off until the AOT plugin will handle assets.

Long story short, `resourceOverride` removes template/styles from `@Component` to remove space and let the AOT compiler handle them.
If you have resources in components then they won't get copied...

Thanks for the feedback. 

Can you clarify what you mean by "If you have resources in components..."? Aren't all resources in components?

We have a _fonts.scss file which defines styles which point to different fonts under `/assets/fonts`. This gets imported into our app.scss which gets included in app.component.ts styleUrls with encapsulation set to None. This is excessive? Open to suggestions for a better approach here.

In my mind, we would ideally be able to include all assets in our component styles and they would all be hashed in prod builds regardless of relative or root-relative urls. Is there a reason we wouldn't want this?

> If you have resources in components...

Resources, such as jpeg, png, fonts etc... 

Usually, application wide resources (such as `_fonts.scss`) should be located in an application wide style sheet and not in a component specific style sheet.  
We have integrated global styles recently, see this [folder](https://github.com/AngularClass/angular2-webpack-starter/tree/master/src/styles)

Having said that, you can solve your issue but the problem remains, the `NgcWebpackPlugin` with AOT compilation **and resourceOverride activated** does not support the `file-loader` or any other loader that emits multiple files from a single source.

For example, a loader gets a CSS files as an input an emits the css file content + 1 JPEG file that it found in a `url('...')` reference.

The reason is AOT compiler runs and passes templates/styles through webpack. Webpack does it's job, if `file-url` is activated it will replaces the content as normal.  
However, that is a different webpack and it only do loader chain so the files never get copied.

Next phase is bundling, again webpack (different instance) runs but this time all of those templates/styles are empty (`resourceOverride`) so hash files not copied.

If hashes are not created then the plugin that copies all asset folder cover up this issue, if hashes are created then that's a problem

> The assets plugin cover up is only valid if all assets are in the assets folder...

This is a tricky issue, it involves a lot of webpack internals... handling cache and invalidation, making sure an asset that was hashed would be copied but it's origin wont... I will fix it...
Ah, gotcha. Ok, thanks for the explanation. Makes things much clearer for us.

Please check version 1.2.0 of `ngc-webpack`, should solve your issue.

I'd appreciate if you can replay with the results.
Terrific! Will try this tonight. Thanks again!
Works great! Closing this issue.
Thanks

It's not quite that simple but you have two options, split or shake.

* **What is the current behavior?**
It seems that "server:dev:hmr" includes HMR twice in the resulting bundle. The message "[WDS] Hot Module Replacement enabled." appears twice as well as change detection messages and so on.

* **If the current behavior is a bug, please provide the steps to reproduce and if possible a minimal demo of the problem**
Just clone the starter project and run "npm run server:dev:hmr".

* **What is the expected behavior?**
I guess it should be included only once?

* **What is the motivation / use case for changing the behavior?**
It may cause some side effects during usage of HMR mode.

* **Other information**
I'm pretty sure that the current behaviour is not expected since there is the following statement in index.html:
`<% if (htmlWebpackPlugin.options.metadata.isDevServer && htmlWebpackPlugin.options.metadata.HMR !== true) { %>`

The second statement cannot evaluate correctly since HMR is not set. Thus "webpack-dev-server.js" will be included although it should not be since we are running HMR mode.

It's a simple fix, i can provide a pull-request if necessary.

Hello all, I use and really appreciate this seed, but there is one thing that keeps me awake at night... 

* **What kind of change does this PR introduce?**
In this PR I've moved development dependencies that are mandatory to make a build (and only them) into normal dependencies.


* **What is the current behavior?**
For now, when someone tries to make a build in a production environment (`NPM_CONFIG_PRODUCTION`=`true`, `NODE_ENV`=`'production'`) dev dependencies are not downloaded while some of them are required to make a build. Developer will be getting many different errors, like:
>     Error: Cannot find module 'awesome-typescript-loader'
>     Cannot find type definition file for 'chai'.
>     sh: 1: webdriver-manager: not found
until he moves all needed deps or perchance installs them manually. It's time-wasting and the solutions are not always obvious (e.g. `webdriver-manager` command comes from `protractor` repository). 
With current behavior it is impossible to deploy application i.e. on Heroku.


* **What is the new behavior?**
After this change production (and development) build runs smothly.

I will be happy to have it merged and respected in the future or to see better solution. Thanks in advance!

My opinion is that dependencies are what is actually include in or used by the built app and devDependencies are all the tools for the build process. Generally you shouldn't have `NODE_ENV="production"` set when you `npm install` if you intend to make a build.

This is a CI / CD issue that needs to be addressed in your delivery workflow.

`devDependencies` exist as to not bloat the size of the production application which at the end of the day is payload a user has to download. This is not something we would be interested in changing here and I can't stress to you how important it is you don't do this in your application.
So what solution would you recommend to deploy `angular2-webpack-starter`-based application i.e. on Heroku?

@DanielKucal 

Option 1) Pre-build and push the final product to Heroku
Option 2) `heroku config:set NPM_CONFIG_PRODUCTION=false`

https://devcenter.heroku.com/articles/nodejs-support#devdependencies

Support the [Dynamic import proposal](https://github.com/tc39/proposal-dynamic-import) [TC39 Stage 3] as a loader (codegen).
The import() construct is supported in webpack from 2.1.0-beta28

> "async-system" is deprecated in webpack 2 and removed in webpack 3.

Moving to 2.0.0 requires a subtle change in the TS loader order.

**Dev's that just upgrade the packages will have some trouble locating this change in the configs so we might expect some noise**

Reason for change:
Typescript transform `import(...)` syntax into something else.
To use `ng-router-loader` with `async-import` code generator the `ng-router-loader` must
 run **AFTER** the TS compiler (e.g: awesome-typescript-loader), that is in a lower index in the loaders array. If it runs before, TS will see the `import(...` expression and will convert it into invalid code.

This change also requires the code generators to emit ES5 code, all codegen's now emit ES5 code.

SEE: Microsoft/TypeScript#12364

@colinskow that's actually not related.

The modules are loaded at startup due to the route strategy, this is configurable.

They are still asynchronous, they just load automatically at startup but a separate bundle is there for each module.

This update doesn't add new functionality, it's more syntax related.

End result for all async code styles (require.ensure, System.import and import()) is logically the same...

Outside of Patrick's approval, we need to get decent documentation around this with all the other routing docs. Most of the users of this starter don't follow TypeScript issues / TC-39 like we do.

Worth noting that in 2.0.0 you had to move the loader to the top only if you wanted to use `asyn-import`, that is, use the new  `import()` dynamic module loading construct.

In 2.1.0 it is required for **all** use cases since I switched to JS AST, if you sent TS to the loader it will fail... 

It doesn't make sense to use the TS compiler here since angular can run on raw JS code

@d3viant0ne, last commit reasoning

The definition of the `*.ts` loader is getting more complex.
We need AOT compliance so we use `angular2-template-loader`
We need lazy loading so we use `ng-router-loader`
And of course, we need to compile TS to JS, `awesome-typescript-loader`

We can't explain all that in the configuration file but we can use Webpack 2 new loader syntax and use objects instead of literal string to configure the loaders.

@d3viant0ne Please review https://github.com/AngularClass/angular2-webpack-starter/wiki/Routing-and-Lazy-loading-@NgModules

Comments are welcome

This upgrades to ngc-webpack 1.1.2

In 1.1.0 depends on `@angular/tsc-wrapper` and `@angular/compiler-cli`

When `@angular/compiler-cli` bumps `@angular/tsc-wrapper` then **ngc-webpack** needs to do so as well... which is not ideal.

`@angular/compiler-cli` actually is `@angular/tsc-wrapper` since it re-exports all of the tsc-wrapper api... 

1.1.2 uses `@angular/compiler-cli` only.

I had a break when trying to compile a complex setup, took me 1 hour to find the culprit, `@angular/compiler-cli` was using `@angular/tsc-wrapper` 0.5.1 while **ngc-webpack** was using 0.5.0 :/

This PR improves the efficiency of the TypeScript build and resolves several issues that result from TypeScript compiling unnecessary files.

The current behavior is that on every build TypeScript compiles every single `.ts` file in the project tree. This is inefficient and can lead to issues when different files in the project require different configurations or use conflicting Typings.

The solution is to tell TypeScript specifically which entry files to compile, and it will automatically compile all their needed dependencies too. With this configuration TypeScript avoids compiling unnecessary files. `awesome-typescript-loader` doesn't seem to support passing in a configuration object, so this PR introduces a Webpack plugin which writes a temporary `tsconfig.json` file containing the correct entry files.

The only drawback is that lazy loaded modules need to be declared in `src/app/lazy-loaded.ts` or they will not get compiled. Maybe @shlomiassaf can write a script that automatically detects and adds them.

- Resolves #1366 
- Improves #1364 

Overall this PR makes builds faster, avoids some Typings conflict issues, and makes watch mode more efficient by watching only necessary files. It is also needed for my Electron branch to separately watch the main and renderer builds.

Looks like Awesome TypeScript Loader is going to make this much easier to implement, so might as well wait until this issue is resolved before merging.
https://github.com/s-panferov/awesome-typescript-loader/issues/364

@colinskow This introduces a lot of pitfalls.

The main one is the need to specify all of your lazy modules in a special file.
It makes lazy loading difficult more than it already is... lazy loading should be part of the route definition flow without extra requirements... 
This alone is a blocker for me...

Also, the final tsconfig is not known to the user, very blurry...

I think it will create more confusion, we better wait for s-panferov/awesome-typescript-loader#364

@shlomiassaf 

There are two ways TypeScript can work with lazy loaded modules:
1) Compile every single file in the project
2) Compile entry files, plus declared lazy loaded modules

If you want to avoid compiling everything, then there is no way around declaring lazy loaded modules. Remember when we used to have to declare vendor libraries?

The way around this would be to write a script that parses the dependency tree and detects lazy loaded modules on its own. But that's a lot of work for very little productivity gain in my eyes.

@colinskow I'm not sure you are right, if this is the case lazy routes would never have worked and this is exactly why `ng-router-loader` exists.

Although `ng-router-loader` kicks in after `awesome-typescript-loader` finished TS to JS conversion it still adds a reference to a file (which is TS).
Webpack will load this file and send it through TS loader chain.

So anyway, the files goes through TS compilation hence TS type checking.

If `awesome-typescript-loader` will typecheck everything in the path of the entryPoint we're good.

For example, `ng-router-loader` will convert this:
<S_CODE_TOKEN>

into this:
<S_CODE_TOKEN>

Now this is pure JS code at this point but webpack will parse it to see if there are any `require` statements or `import()` in this case.

Since there are it will load them, since this points to a TS file it will go through the TS chain... all good.

`'awesome-typescript-loader?{configFileName: "tsconfig.webpack.json"}',`

`'awesome-typescript-loader?{tsconfig: "tsconfig.webpack.json"}',`

This appears to be a bug affecting just Windows with TypeScript 2.1.5. It goes away when downgrading to TypeScript 2.0.10.

But I found a better solution:
Just above `"types:"` in both `tsconfig.json` files add the following:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

TypeScript should [automatically look there](https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/tsconfig-json.html#types-typeroots-and-types), but it appears this is failing on Windows.

@vogloblinsky Dropped a comment in another issue in regards to switching from TypeDoc to Compodoc and was kind enough to spin up a demo - https://compodoc.github.io/angular2-webpack-starter/

The options are ...

- Keep TypeDoc.
- Switch to Compodoc.
- Drop doc generation and let users add what they will.

Personally I don't run docs on my applications currently, though [Compodoc](https://github.com/compodoc/compodoc) is the first offering that has the potential to drive enough value to warrant the addition.

//cc @colinskow @katallaxie @shlomiassaf

I Don't have much to contribute on this...

I saw the product that `TypeDoc` produces, doesnt seem to be impressive.
But this is just theming... 

The Compodoc looks better, I must admit. 

If we consider things that does not belong to the starter, docs can easily fit in...
That said, promoting a doc system might help people document their OS code so it's good for the community.

I'm on board :)

If I need to choose, I would go with Compodoc, that's totally intuition nothing to back it up with :)
I don't generate docs at the moment, so I don't have an opinion here. But it is definitely something useful to have a demo of in the repo, and I may consider using it if there is a good example.

Currently TypeDoc is part of the project and I know at least some people use it. It has consistently had maintenance issues so we either need to remove it and let people manage their own docs or switch to Compodoc.

Personally I'm leaning towards the latter, we need a good doc generation tool and it's by far the best to come down the pipe. Can't hurt to support a new lib, particularly one with as much promise as it holds for utility.

@d3viant0ne 
Yes compodoc is at the beginning, with some features which needs to be enhanced.
The target release 0.1.0 will add the last missing features for a matured tool.
I will update this discussion when it will be ready.

Wait for the following Compodoc's roadmap point to be done:
 - handle external markdown files as "functional" documentation

For now my modular app has some "library modules" that i get via npm, and store in "node_modules/@my-project-scope/some-isolated-functionality-module"
Unfortunately compodoc cant include documentation for them and i have only documentation for my app skeleton
@DyckGerman - I'm in the same boat there. I do much the same thing for my ui platform at work and have run into the same issue.

Already done.

Protractor `^5.0.0` dropped support Node 5. If we want to upgrade Protractor further we will need to drop support for Node 5. Other deps will likely do the same in order to use ES6 code natively.

In my opinion we should focus on Node versions from LTS to latest.

Touchy subject as many people are for a reason I honestly can't understand still using node 4.x.

I personally agree, support LTS + Next with a grace period for the previous LTS & dev version. If we are going to do this, we need to put out a warning via pretty much every way possible and give it a few weeks to soak in before we pull the trigger imo.

ohhh no, winter is coming :)

I would go LTS... 

This is a starter project, it should use the latest and greatest with responsibility... so LTS sound good.
To be clear, I completely agree with the current LTS + Next approach we just need to be ready for the torches & pitch forks from the slow adopters when we drop 4.x support :)

Angular 2 (and thus we) dropped support for 4.x some time ago. Node 5 passed quickly, so I don't expect many people stuck with it.

The reason 6 is important is because it has full ES6 support. That's why things are breaking on previous versions. I expect future versions should be stable for a while until Node starts adding ES 2016/17 support perhaps in 8.

Just a side note, we can still run < LTS with some scripting before running...
Something like running removing protractor 5 installing 4 and just running the build & tests w/o e2e...

This makes < LTS support limited but there...

I agree with the LTS + Next version. Node already defines road map for versions.

A simple version pairing note on readme should do the trick for the less informed.

- Cleaned up NPM scripts, removed redundant & deprecated ones
- Fixed e2e:live
- Updated README with info on DLLs, external stylesheets, and updated scripts
- Travis script also tests dev/dll build
- Added delay in Travis script to reduce likelihood of failure

Resolves #1353
Protractor ^5.0.0 dropped support Node 5. If we want to update Protractor further we will need to drop support for Node 5. In my opinion we should support only Node lastest and Node LTS.

@katallaxie you haven't submitted a pull request for i18n yet!
https://angular.io/docs/ts/latest/cookbook/i18n.html

* **I'm submitting a ...**
[ x] bug report
[] feature request
[ ] question about the decisions made in the repository

* **Do you want to request a *feature* or report a *bug*?**
bug  - but maybe a feature :-)


* **What is the current behavior?**

Currently if you have run an aot build and have a compiled/ folder, and then run the dev server, then at-loader runs across the compiled directory also, which increases compile time by a couple of seconds, but also shows errors if constructor injections in src folder change. 

* **If the current behavior is a bug, please provide the steps to reproduce and if possible a minimal demo of the problem** 

With a fresh copy of repo run the start:hmr and check at-loader completion times, then run build:aot, and then start:hmr again - at-loader times possible increased by several seconds.

If you delete compiled folder or change excludes in tsconfig.webpack.json to the following then at-loader completion times go down again.

  "exclude": [
    "node_modules",
    "dist",
    "compiled",
    "src/**/*.spec.ts",
    "src/**/*.e2e.ts"
  ]

The above change does not appear to affect the AoT build process at all.
Maybe cleaning the compiled folder at the start of the dev server task is a better option?

* **What is the expected behavior?**

Existence of the compiled folder shouldn't affect dev build at all?

* **What is the motivation / use case for changing the behavior?**

The extra at-loader completion time is not such a big issue, but getting at-loader errors about code in the compiled folder when running dev task is annoying.

* **Please tell us about your environment:**
- Angular version: 2.4.1
Windows

Currently the at-loader is using the same configuration file for AoT and JiT builds. `node_modules` is necessary to include since `@angular` and other dependencies live there. Excluding `*.spec.ts` and `*.e2e.ts` could possibly shave a few dozen milliseconds off each build.

We could also try specifying `"rootDir": "./src"` in `tsconfig.webpack.json` and see if that prevents unnecessary files from being scanned.

As far as `compiled` I usually run `npm run clean:aot` to remove this folder before doing a non-AoT build.

Excluding files is like putting a bandaid over a deeper problem. I'm working on a PR that will cause TypeScript to compile only dependent files and ignore everything else. This will make builds run more efficiently.
Ok  - thanks - no need to keep this one open then.

@glendaviesnz by the way if you are getting compiler errors from compiled while running other scripts, then you are probably running older versions of dependencies. Try upgrading everything to the same versions in master. I don't get errors.

This is a good idea. `poll: false` won't work inside VirtualBox and a few other situations, but we can leave a commented note for those folk. This will improve performance for everybody else. In addition we could probably further improve watch performance with `ignored: /node_modules/`.

https://webpack.js.org/configuration/watch/

@colinskow May as well roll this into the webpack config rework and make it a configurable option for the user.

I'll rework them later this evening

@colinskow @abhishekisnot @d3viant0ne @gdi2290 

This is my take on DLL integration: Using a plugin to control the whole process.

The plugin internally injects the low level DLL plugins provided by webpack (`DllPlugin`, `DllRegerencePlugin`) into the webpack instances.

The plugin handles both the webpack instance it get's registered on and a new webpack instance it creates for bundle generation.

The sole purpose of this plugin is to detect changes to the bundle structure.

Few points:
  - The plugin is async (promises). This is for future support of webpack package resolution (currently using node). This is important since webpack can resolve from other directories other then `node_module`.

  - The plugin is ready for live re-bundling. It detects a change in the package level so it can trigger a build per bundle. This will come in handy once live re-bundling is supported.

  - No need for extra configuration, everything is in the plugin, no extra commands.  
This makes it super easy to opt-out, just remove the plugin from `plugins`

> If a package is missing the process will throw (using the current config), it will not install from `npm` or `yarn`. This is how it should be, the plugin is not responsible for fetching packages, it just bundles the existing. 

[See source code](https://github.com/shlomiassaf/webpack-dll-bundles-plugin)

Change to the repo is minimal.

### PLEASE DO NOT MERGE UNTIL DISCUSSION ENDS

I did not have time for unit tests and proper documentation, I this PR is accepted I will appreciate any help on tests, documentation and adding support to some features.

Thanks.

@shlomiassaf that's impressive! You took what I did to a higher level. Obviously it's better to handle the DLL build inside a Webpack plugin rather than the npm scripts.

Just a couple small points:
1) Add a `clean:dll` NPM script, and also add the `dll` folder to the `clean` script.
2) You should think about unit testing the logic of your package (outside the Webpack build)

The bottom line is that DLLs make dev builds run a lot faster, once the DLLs are built. This is a good merge as long as it doesn't have unexpected side effects or break existing builds that otherwise work.

Another idea is to extract the DLL into a separate config file (I used `dll.config.js`). Since each developer will likely modify this list, this way they can pull updates from the starter with less work.

* **What kind of change does this PR introduce?** (Bug fix, feature, docs update, ...)

Style improvement.

* **What is the current behavior?** (You can also link to an open issue here)

Currently the `root` function in the `helpers` module has some unpleasant code deemed necessary for compatibility reasons. It manipulates the arguments object via `Array.prototype.slice.call` and rebinds its actual argument which is a bad practice and is also confusing since the argument's value is ignored and it is effectively used as a variable.

* **What is the new behavior (if this is a feature change)?**

Cleans up the function and reduces code size.

I am going to be creating a version of this repo specifically for building [Electron](http://electron.atom.io) apps. Electron is quite heavy so this would be inappropriate for the main branch.

Main changes will be:
- Inclusion of Electron dependencies
- The addition of a separate build for the Electron main process
- Karma tests will run inside Electron
- E2E tests will be redone to use [Spectron](http://electron.atom.io/spectron/) instead of Protractor

The current Angular 2 build process will remain practically unchanged, so it should be easy to maintain those files in sync with this repo.

My question: is AngularClass interested in maintaining this in a separate branch, or should I build it as my own fork? Once it is built, I could definitely use help maintaining it as technology evolves.

We have historically not been very consistent in the maintenance of feature branches and I have always been partial to the approach @mgechev took where major features were maintained in forks with a link to them added to the readme of the base.

Keeps the issues & pull requests focused a bit better imo.

I'm currently working on setting up double watch builds, one for Electron and one for the Renderer. Whenever an Electron dependency is updated it should restart Electron (via electron-connect). And then I will connect the Renderer process to the Hot Module Reloader via a [custom server script](https://github.com/chentsulin/electron-react-boilerplate/blob/master/server.js).

I found a [bug](https://github.com/s-panferov/awesome-typescript-loader/issues/351) in `awesome-typescript-loader` that causes Webpack to watch every single .ts file in the project, no matter what. So I'm working on getting the main and renderer builds to refresh independently only when their dependencies are updated. (Right now I've resorted to monkey-patching my installation of ATL.)

The other project I am working on is replacing Protractor with [Spectron](http://electron.atom.io/spectron/) since Protractor doesn't work well with Electron.

Maybe we can work together or at least rip code off each other ;-)

Quick remarks from my very quick look at it:

1. I think electron.main should be on a dedicated folder in root. This is because you potentially want to extend electron main capabilities and have multiple files for it.

2. I don't think NGRX fits this starter. That is why I created an advanced starter. NGRX is just too complex for most devs starting with angular2.

Would you be willing to implement your electron improvements in my [advanced starter](https://github.com/JonnyBGod/angular2-webpack-advance-starter)?

@JonnyBGod thank you for the feedback.

1. I created a separate `electron` folder inside `src` to place sub-modules for the main process. It felt awkward having them outside of the `src` tree. Ideally I would use a different folder structure, but I want to keep everything the same so I can easily pull updates from this repo.

2. Most devs who are just starting with Angular2 should be using Angular-CLI. This repo is really for those of us who aren't satisfied with CLI and are obsessed with customizing the build. Redux/ngrx is the absolute best way to manage state and scaling without it is a headache. I included a very simple implementation (one reducer, one action). It wanted to show how to hook it up to HMR, unit tests, and the Redux DevTools extension since that is tricky.

I just setup several DevTools extensions which will automatically install themselves in development mode.

Feel free to pull what you want from my code. I'm using specialized Electron code, so my fork no longer supports browser builds.
