* **What kind of change does this PR introduce?** (Bug fix, feature, docs update, ...)
*feature*

* **What is the current behavior?** (You can also link to an open issue here)
Feature #1345 

* **What is the new behavior (if this is a feature change)?**
AutoPrefixer will add vendor prefixes after this PR is merged.

* **Other information**:
> The `*.scss` loader was missing from `webpack.test.js` which was causing failures if one had scss file in a component.
> It's probably better to add [null-loader](https://github.com/webpack/null-loader) for `*.css` and `*.scss` in test configuration. Maybe we can create a separate PR for that.

I think the question to ask is how many developers need this. Most modern browsers support just about all CSS tags without prefix now. This is not needed for Safari, Chrome, Firefox and IE10+.

This is going to slow the build slightly and add size to compiled CSS. The purpose of this repo is to provide a starting point for majority use-cases. This is an easy modification to make for those who have a specific need for it.

I am pretty sure the stance on autoprefixer in the past was if people want to use it, they can add it but @gdi2290 didn't want it in the starter as it adds more complexity for limited usefulness.

Personally I agree with @colinskow in regards to this being a starting point and thus we really only want to include things that are of benefit to everyone using the starter to build upon.

We also need to keep in mind that every new feature adds regression debt.

IMO, the purpose of this starter is to provide the best build process, that does the essentials, in zero time.
It also needs to include some demo's for main features like lazy loading, injection etc...

Now, I can live with SCSS since it is considered essential but any post css out there is not.

I think the rule of thumb should be, will it work without it?
Not having a SCSS loader means SCSS will not work, so include it.
Not having an auto prefixer, still everything works.. dont include it.

Next thing will be adding translation support just cause it's cool :)

Again, IMO, This is the same approach we need to take with DLLs, its not essential nor expected by developers, it's still an "early" concept and make entry level users run away...
Yep, it's cool to have I agree, but this is a highly used repository so people should understand what's happening.

@shlomiassaf just to be clear the case for the DLLs pull request is that it cuts dev build time in half, which leads to dramatic productivity gains -- especially when repeatedly testing small changes in code or debugging. It's a money maker for the companies who will use this starter.

The DLLs are setup so they are totally transparent to the user, who gets automatic immediate productivity gains as soon as we test and merge the PR. It's not going to scare new people away since they don't need to get into technical details (which is just one plugin added to the dev build chain). It also shouldn't break any existing builds.

@shlomiassaf I could live with Autoprefixer + PostCSS, rather then SCSS 🤕 . There are many projects that use different CSS preprocessors. However, there are litte differences as to what is need in the postprocessing, which is minifcation, inlining, and compatibility.

We are going to stay the course here. If a developer wants / needs PostCSS / Autoprefixer they can add it to their project. 

Closes ##1345

* **What is the motivation / use case for changing the behavior?**
It can often become a bit tedious to include all the vendor prefixes for the CSS you use. Use an auto-prefixer to automatically add the prefixes you need to include.

* **Other information**
[autoprefixer](https://github.com/postcss/autoprefixer) is a PostCSS plugin to parse CSS and add vendor prefixes to CSS rules using values from [Can I Use](http://caniuse.com/). It is [recommended](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/setup/setup-buildtools#dont_trip_up_with_vendor_prefixes) by Google and used in Twitter and Taobao.
Refer #1347 for discussion on this.

* **What kind of change does this PR introduce?** (Bug fix, feature, docs update, ...)
Upgrade to `ngc-webpack@1.1.0`

* **Other information**:
`ngc-webpack@1.1.0` comes with 2 major improvements:

  - Run the angular complier from the `NgcWebpackPlugin`  
this makes configuration easier, removes cli steps and provides more control over the compilation

  - Remove `@Component` resources (template/styles) from the bundle.  
This is actually a great improvement to bundle size...
For each `@Component` the AOT compiler compiles it creates new representation for the templates (html, styles) of that `@Components`. It means that there is no need for the source templates, they take a lot of space... **Webpack** bundles out source files and the compiler files (`ngfactory`) so we get 2 versions of the same template/style in our bundle.  
This feature is `NormalModuleReplacementPlugin` for identified resources... the templates are replaced with empty files.

This PR introduces DLLs to dramatically speed up development builds. This theoretically should have zero side effects and not break any existing builds. (Although we should test thoroughly in the wild before merging.) The `check-dlls` script automatically detects when DLLs are missing or out of date (when the installed packages they reference change versions) and rebuilds them only when needed.

These enhancements are completely transparent to the developer. The user doesn't have to do anything to get performance benefits, but can edit `config/dll.config.js` to add additional packages to the DLL build. Anything that is missing will end up in common chunks and not cause any breakage (but won't be as fast as it could be).

In addition I:
- Added the DLL dev build to the `npm run ci` test so we don't break it by accident in the future
- Cleaned up the NPM scripts and removed some redundant ones that were getting called twice during builds
- Updated the README with DLL info and instructions for external stylesheets

So far I've tested this PR on MacOS Sierra and Windows 10.
Not sure how much time we would save on polyfills DLL alone. Is it worth adding polyfills DLL to prod build? I suppose AOT does not look at polyfills.

No, it doesn't. You are never going to see a real time savings in the starter or most of the applications built on top of it less the very largest applications. But hey, the masses just had to have the next hot buzz word, regardless of their understanding of it's benefits and @colinskow was kind enough to provide.

On my MacBook Pro I'm getting 11,003ms dev build time for master, and 6345ms for DLL branch dev build. That's almost 5 seconds faster or a 40% gain. This isn't much time on one build, but when a developer is repeatedly testing code changes in watch mode it adds up quick.

I don't think it will provide any benefits to production builds though.

* **Do you want to request a *feature* or report a *bug*?**
*feature*


* **What is the current behavior?**
Currently the starter supports only Angular 2+ applications.

* **What is the expected behavior?**
Support bootstraping Angular 1 & Angular 2+ hybrid applications.


* **What is the motivation / use case for changing the behavior?**
Many of enterprise applications are still on Angular 1 and potentially most (or many?) of them would want to migrate to Angular 2. Assuming ngUpgrade is a de-facto solution for such an upgrade, it would be great if this starter supported bootstraping hybrid application as outlined here https://angular.io/docs/ts/latest/guide/upgrade.html#!#bootstrapping-hybrid-angular-1-2-applications


* **Other information**
* This feature I suppose should be an opt in/out.. But currently we do not have any strategy for opt in/out.
* We are raising this request in an attempt to explore possibility of such a support and also to gather feedback if this needs to be done in a fork

The requirements to support any number of angular 1.x versions is a rabbit hole filled with stylistically & architecturally different upgrade applications.

- This is beyond the scope of what this was built for.
- It would add a bunch of bloat for the remainder of the community who won't ever use it.
- Too many ngUpgrade quirks to not purpose build a solution.

In short, there is no good way to take the one size fits all approach to upgrading existing 1.x applications. It's certainly possible to modify the starter to support an upgrade path, it is not on the other hand something I see as beneficial for this repo or it's consumers.

//cc @katallaxie @colinskow @gdi2290

@d3viant0ne 👍 Upgrade is seriously beyond what this starter wants to achieve. Also, it seems that in most cases it would be more beneficial, if we would provide something like `angular2-recipes` in which we provide some patterns and examples.

> any number of angular 1.x versions is a rabbit hole...

@d3viant0ne On same page here, maybe we can pick latest version and just keep it limited to that.

> It would add a bunch of bloat for the remainder of the community who won't ever use it.

I guess this is where opt in/out can be considered? If still complicated, maybe we can resort to `angular2-recipes` as @katallaxie said.

> Too many ngUpgrade quirks to not purpose build a solution.

Agreed. Easy or Hard, I guess we would still need a support of some sort in form of build solution or receipes considering ngUpgrade is a de-facto solution for upgrading. 

Also, it's fine if we agree that it's something out of the scope for this starter. 

What I was wondering is, we have [NG6-starter](https://github.com/AngularClass/NG6-starter) for NG1.x apps and this starter for NG2+ apps, it would be great if we have a build solution (or even receipes) that connects these 2 starters.

That was kind of my point, they shouldn't be connected. This starter exists to facilitate the development of an Angular version 2.x or newer application. It doesn't support ngupgrade and shouldn't as you are adding a a bunch of functionality / complexity / bloat for a niche requirement outside the scope of this repo.

Adding things into master means we are making a technology choice for thousands of people, those choices need to be made with the best interests of the users & the library in mind. 

Adding opt in / out support for ngupgrade, regardless of limiting version is not in the best interest of either the majority of the consumers or the repo nor would we want to assume the maintenance costs of the validations and issues that would come along with it.

Furthermore in my personal opinion this is not something that I would ever choose to undertake professionally using a generic boilerplate. If you have requirements that necessitate the use of ngupgrade and all it's quirks, I would strongly encourage you to purpose build the base of that project using whatever starting point you deem appropriate for you and your team.

Tree shaking is all setup in master and there's nothing else you need to do. `tsconfig.webpack.json` is set to export ES2015 modules which is what Webpack 2 needs for tree shaking. The `vendor.ts` file has been removed and all packages from inside `node_modules` will automatically be tree shaken put into the vendor bundle.

Note that tree shaking doesn't happen with CommonJS `require()` modules so only packages which use `import` will benefit.

@Ks89 you can put any global imports such as Boostrap into `app.module.ts`.

Any imports that are parsed through your entry point that are inside `node_modules` will automatically be extracted into a vendor bundle. You no longer need to declare them manually in `vendor.ts` since the process is automatic.

Feature


* **What is the current behavior?**
Build Times are high since we are compiling/linking/building all the vendor libs every time we start the application in dev mode. 

* **What is the expected behavior?**
Build Times can be little lower using separate compilations of vendor libs.

* **What is the motivation / use case for changing the behavior?**
We can leverage Webpack's ability to do compiling/linking/building in a separate build step to optimize the build times as outlined here -- http://webpack.github.io/docs/build-performance.html#dynamic-linked-library

This feature as implemented in angular-seed -- https://github.com/AngularClass/angular-seed/blob/master/src/dll.ts

This would definitely be useful for the development build. However, it isn't ideal for the production build since tree shaking doesn't happen.

[angular-webpack2-starter](https://github.com/qdouble/angular-webpack2-starter) has this working perfectly, so it is just a matter of copying the code and specifying the packages we need as DLLs. This will require us to move quite a bit of code out of `webpack.common.js` since development and production build processes will be different.

@colinskow We need to be very careful with DLL's.

It's a feature worth having for large scale projects but it will require a big refactor...

We need to figure how how can we do it so people will opt-in and not get it by default...

The other starter with DLL's is super complicated with one huge config that is very hard to understand...

There's a balance...

In short, yes we will add DLL support in the future but as stated above we will have to rewrite most of the webpack configs to provide the proper development experience & avoid causing headaches for those who have extended the starter.

IMO if we are going to go through the trouble, we should probably implement it using something like webpack blocks & handle the opt in/out that way.

Regardless of implementation, it's something that really needs to be planned out in advance and then executed to prevent ending up in the weeds.

Good news, building on @abhishekisnot's pull request I've gotten this working in a way that doesn't require refactor and is highly unlikely to break any existing builds.

The DLL packages must be specified manually in a config file, but anything not included there will simply fall back into the common chunks. I'm even working on a script that will intelligently update the DLLs when a dependent package changes.

This will require testing in the wild to ensure it doesn't break anything, but I think it should be safe to enable by default rather than opt-in, which would complicate things with lots of additional build scripts. The dev build speed benefits are huge.

https://plnkr.co or similar (you can use this template as a starting point: http://plnkr.co/edit/tpl:AvJOMERrnz94ekVua0u5).
1) Debugging TypeScript code works correctly with sourcemaps in version before v5.2.0 (02716cc21a3f53f62f12aad5ae22c20dbe421048), so try that, e.g. home.component.
2) Debugging in any version after (02716cc21a3f53f62f12aad5ae22c20dbe421048) does not work as expected. Breakpoints are hit in incorrect locations and cannot be set in others.

Correct sourcemaps for debugging with TypeScript.

I will try to be more clear, it has nothing to do with AOT itself, I am not even using it, but since the release that you have flagged as version v5.2.0, where you introduced AOT support in the setup, debugging does not work in Chrome and Edge for example. I have now identified what is causing this. The change from module "commonjs" to "es2015" in compilerOptions (tsconfig.webpack.json) breaks the debugging support. I have now changed it back to commonjs and now it works again, what is the downside to this if any? Why the change to es2015 and why does that break debugging? Please update the config to work even for debugging scenarios.
What version of node are you running in your dev environment?

@WillooWisp changing the module type to "es2015" enables tree shaking, which dramatically reduces the bundle size in production builds.

Seems like it is related to this issue: https://github.com/webpack/webpack/issues/2145

They suggest changing `devtool` (in `config/webpack.dev.js`) to `eval-source-map`. It may be slightly slower, but breakpoints should work. (You should also experiment with different devtools to see what works and gives you optimum build time.)

The other options is to create a separate `tsconfig.webpack.dev.json` with `commonjs` module type for dev builds, since tree shaking doesn't make any difference here.

This will hopefully be fixed by the final release of Webpack 2.

You probably don't understand the limitations `angular-router-loader` brings with it, if your webpack configuration is simple, yes it will works but it limits all of the goodies webpack provides... 

The problem itself probably relates to fact that `ng-router-loader` is asynchronous so it can use webpack to resolve paths.

Anyone who knows how webpack works realises the problem with the synchronous file system approach.

@d3viant0ne The problem described by @pglazkov @pleerock fit's an issue that might happen with the older implementation (non AST).

The old process used regex with replace to transform the code.
On a module, if multiple lazy routes were set the old process had to take each and replace it.
Before replacing we need to resolve the actual file, this is an async process.
So since each "replace" is **async** I had to store the whole module code in memory and each replace that returned did the actual replace on that in memory "source".

The problem described above shows that some lazy paths were not replaced, which might indicate some race condition but I couldn't reproduce it, I tried 2000 lazy modules, no luck.

What's more confusing is that **async** is not a parallel, every instruction runs alone in the vm so I don't really understand what happened there.

My best guess is that it happens on win machines.

Anyways, I decided to refactor and use AST which is more accurate. I also made sure all changes happens sync.

You can take a look in [this branch](https://github.com/shlomiassaf/angular2-webpack-starter/tree/ng-router-loader-2000-lazy-modules), 2000 lazy modules, works for me.

I can only guess since there's not a lot of information...

But it looks like you're trying to load a global scss file from within a component styleUrls... right?

@shlomiassaf  : You are correct, this happens also in my case, the scss files are being loaded directly through the component's styleUrls. 

An Idea would be to configure the `test: /\.scss$/` rule to work with `"extract-text-webpack-plugin": "^2.0.0-beta.4",` so we can extract css files into the components' dirs and change our `templateUrl` reference to point to this?

@feddyups No, `test: /\.scss$/` is to generic, it will take all SCSS files and send them to the header.

There are 2 types of stylesheets in an angular 2 application
 - Global styles (goes to head)
 - Component styles (live within the component)

Each component has a `ViewEncapsulation` property that defines the interaction of the styles so it's important to have SCSS files stay within the component.

Global styles can be in a specific app or prefixed, it's up to you actually (see #1304 and comments)

@BkSouX The error you posted indicates that the `@angular/compiler` tried to fetch a resource that was in the `styleUrls` of a component but it wasn't there.

This error also indicates that you are using an older version of this repo since this resource is loaded by the `compiler-cli` and not `ngc-webpack`

Anyway, if the file is not present `ngc-webpack` will throw as well...

@d3viant0ne @colinskow @qdouble 

**What is the current behavior?** (You can also link to an open issue here)
When using AOT compilation, `@Component` templates (HTML, CSS, SCSS, etc...) are not running through the webpack loader chain.

Development output might not be the same as AOT output.

For example, CSS that goes through `postCSS` processing (autoprefixing, etc..) will not work when AOT compiling.  

If we want to use SCSS, html transformation or any other webpack goodie we can't.


* **What is the new behavior (if this is a feature change)?**
Use  [ngc wrapper](https://github.com/shlomiassaf/ngc-webpack) to provide resourced after they have passed the webpack loader chain, based on the webpack configuration provided.

The type of resource is irrelevant, if there's a loader configuration for it it will go through it.

This is both a bug submission and a feature request as a solution.


* **What is the current behavior?**
awesome-typescript-loader incorrectly transpiles **const enum**


* **What is the expected behavior?**
awesome-typescript-loader should transpile **const enum** by replacing the variable name, with its respective representative integer.


* **What is the motivation / use case for changing the behavior?**
Please refer to the GitHub issue: [Const enum are preserved and not replaced with actual values #137](https://github.com/s-panferov/awesome-typescript-loader/issues/137)

We are concerned about how many projects in the wild that are being transpiled incorrectly because of this bug.  This issue has been standing in their repository for months without being addressed.  We are making a feature request to consider [ts-loader](https://github.com/TypeStrong/ts-loader) as the choice of loader for the starter kit, as it correctly transpiles **const enum**

[ts-loader](https://github.com/TypeStrong/ts-loader) loader seems to adhere to typescript standard better, and is more responsive to crippling bugs.  We should consider this seriously.
This cannot be replicated with the starter. Using examples from [Enums](https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/enums.html) produces expected results.
It is fine that this is closed.  I thought you should be warned that this behavior does exist for some particular configurations.  Which configurations... who knows. ^_^  Cheers my friend @katallaxie
it would be great if someone can reproduce the error otherwise it's just an awesome-ts side-effect that we can't account for and ts-loader is too slow

In production apps it is a bad practice to inline large CSS files to Javascript, as it can slow initial page load and cause unstyled HTML to flicker.

This PR adds the ability to put SASS or CSS files in the `./src/styles` directory, import them into a module, and they will generate an external CSS file on production builds. On dev builds they are imported using the `style-loader` to support hot module reloading.

@colinskow I used a different take on this.

I used a convention to identify global SCSS files: `some-style.global.scss`

Then a loader:
<S_CODE_TOKEN>

> The component SCSS loader must also `exclude: [/\.global\.scss$/],`

Now all `*.global.scss` files are set in the head.

This is of course not a separate file for styles but it differentiates between global and component local styles.


Now, for having styles in a separate file, this is something I think the developer should decide.

I think we should put the extract plugin to target 1 file, all other files the dev wants to include he should import from that main (and not from JS code).

If he imports from JS code it goes to the head.

**My reasoning about this is that if all styles are in 1 directory it's far more logical to import them all from one file inside that directory, similar to an `index`file in a package/module/barrel.**

I see this directory as the `theme` for the app, plus it's more aligned with SASS `@import`s...

I have a problem with style imports scattered around the project, it's hard tracking their order and that's important for CSS.

The order of the CSS will be the order the files were imported. I've created a styles directory where all the external styles will originate, and I think we should leave it to the developer to choose a convention. They are not scattered around the project, except for the Angular component styles which are inlined with the JS.

I library like Bootstrap can be imported by putting a file in the styles directory and using @import.

@d3viant0ne it doesn't appear we have any disagreements with this PR. @shlomiassaf suggests using the naming convention `*.global.scss` for external stylesheets, but I believe this is not necessary with everything in the `src/styles` directory.

I suggest we merge this so I can start working on other enhancements like DLLs without having to rebase.

1.) Rebase it.

2.) As far as conventions go, they are much like words in scrabble. `Common Use`

In this case, I think it would be best to not enforce conventions on people. If a developer wants to do something like @shlomiassaf is suggesting, they can extend the project as they see fit.

The most common way I have seen / used in regards to scss and 3rd party styles would be to use `@import` in something like `main.scss / styles.scss` at the root of a project or styles directory.

Keep it simple & let the developer make his / her own decisions on conventions.
Rebase completed.

* **What kind of change does this PR introduce?** (Bug fix, feature, docs update, ...)
Bug fix: sourcemaps are no longer enabled by default in the UglifyJS Webpack plugin.


* **What is the current behavior?** (You can also link to an open issue here)
No source maps are generated in a production build.


* **What is the new behavior (if this is a feature change)?**
Source maps are correctly generated.


* **Other information**:

@colinskow - See #1241

This is not something that should be on by default but opt in should a developer choose or need to push production sourcemaps.
As an alternative, An off by default configurable flag would be fine if the idea is to not have to deal with overwriting the config setting. i.e `--sourcemaps` on the build call like env.

This PR adds AoT support using the `ngc` compiler. `@ngtools/webpack` still has many flaws, but this setup is working perfectly. `npm install` and then `npm run ci` to fully test both AoT and JIT builds.

- upgraded Angular to ~2.4.1
- added AoT compile script
- fixed AoT incompatible code in app
- enabled Webpack 2 tree shaking by specifying ES2015 module output
- e2e testing script launches its own server
- ci script will test both AoT and JIT builds, makes fresh builds on each test
- specified `noEmit` typescript flag to prevent accidentally spamming compiled files into the project
- disabled caching on production server to be able to see changes
- updated bad links at top of README
- documented new features in README

Resolves #885
wicked!
Restart the build jobs one at a time. Travis often hangs with concurrent builds.

FYI - I restarted both the travis builds

@d3viant0ne `tsconfig.webpack.json` is correctly named. This is used by `awesome-typescript-loader` to run dev, production, and aot builds. It uses the es2015 module format in order to enable tree shaking.

Karma and other node libraries can't deal with es2015 modules and must use commonjs. That is why I forked the file. One for Webpack's internal use. The other for everything else.
re: `json config` misinterpreted the intent, makes sense.
I've got another incoming commit on this PR to reduce bundle size and enable automatic tree shaking of the vendors bundle.

The AoT build was including lots of unnecessary files so I added a commit which automatically extracts imports from `node_modules` into the vendors module and tree shakes them. This cuts the output bundle size in less than half. Previously there was no tree shaking of vendor imports.

I also added the Webpack Bundle Analyzer plugin and made it accessible by setting the command line flag `--env.analyze`. This allows for easy inspection of output bundles to ensure they are fully optimized. For example: `npm run build:aot:prod -- --env.analyze`.
eagerly waiting for this PR to be merged.

Awesome work, you should also add a script for: npm run start:aot. 
And how can one import bootstrap 4 with that changed logic for referencing vendors?

@katallaxie - AOT should not be the default for `prod` for exactly what @colinskow stated, it breaks things. After a developer has his application running stable on AoT, he or she can default it to AoT in their project. We should be enabling features in a starter, not mandating them.

Given the commitment required to create a large application published AoT, this is a feature that should be off by default & opt in or it's going to break every production build this starter backs when they pick up the changes.

I do on the other hand agree about @katallaxie's comment in regards to the BundleAnalyzerPlugin, It's trivial to add and would suggest this be transfered to Wiki instructions & not added to the seed directly ( it's big ).

We get basic bundle analysis via Webpack RC, if people want all the bells & whistles they can add `BundleAnalyzerPlugin`

@colinskow I get your point. Though, I believe it should be considered best practice to have AoT and deviate from that. So, if you have an application, that for what ever reasons, doesn't work with AoT then you can disable it. But I would see it the other way around. As regarding to `@ngtools/webpack`, I had doubts some months ago, that's why it wasn't in the `aot` branch. Though, I see it as the tool of choice in the long run. You have less boilerplate code, better integration with what Webpack does and better code quality.
@d3viant0ne Because we had some deps fixed, we should take care of them now. We should also update `webpack` to `2.2.0-rc.2` and `webpack-dev-server` to `2.2.0-rc.0`. As for the bundle analysis.

* **What is the current behavior?**
Using async / await in current setup throws exception where __generator is not defined on  ZoneAwarePromise (polyfills.bundle.js).


* **What is the motivation / use case for changing the behavior?**
Being able to use async / await with latest TypeScript 2.1 and es5.


* **Please tell us about your environment:**

- Angular version: 2.2.1
- Browser: Chrome

TypeScript 2.1.x isn't supported by Angular 2.x. You will have to wait until Angular 4.x

Can you explain what you mean with "TypeScript isn't supported by Angular 2.x"? TypeScript is the preferred language when writing Angular 2 apps. Since the async / await is compiled to es5 JavaScript code with the use of a polyfill containing a correctly implemented Promise it should work, or at least I thought so.

Please explain why Angular 2 is a specific problem for this scenario, compared to Angular 4, since it feels like I am missing something here.

Thanks!

Can't see any real info about that it should not work, only some specific cases. I do use TypeScript 2.1.4 together with Angular 2.2.4 and it works great. The problem is the zone promise class being used and cannot be switched out. That promise does not work in conjunction with async / await.

There are other threads around that topic as well. The general consensus is it's not supported and won't be for a while. If you choose to push past what is in Angular's package.json you are in uncharted waters.

Async/Await is a cool feature and i'm sure i'll be leveraging it in another 6 months when it has robust support. You could create an issue over at Angular but i'm all but positive they are going to tell you the same thing.

Still trying to wrap my head around some of this but this was the first start I have seen where the solution still uses # in the URL. Is there a reason that still has to be used? One of the nice things about Angular2 is that we no longer had to deal with # in the URL. Seems there are other features we can't use with this version like moduleId so just wondering if this is another one that can't be used.

Just change the `LocationStrategy` to [PathLocationStrategy](https://angular.io/docs/ts/latest/api/common/index/PathLocationStrategy-class.html). You can use `moduleId` see here: [Component Relative Paths](https://angular.io/docs/ts/latest/cookbook/component-relative-paths.html).
Cool. Thanks for the quick response. That helped educate me.

@dickon - `npm run test` is intended to just run the karma suite.

For the e2e tests, you need to run some sort of server for Protractor to execute against. In a CI environment, that requires additional commands prior to the execution of the e2e tests.

The same is applicable for running the test watcher during active development, where you normally don't want to be running an e2e suite which can involve other services to be running in most data driven applications.

The validations are split intentionally which is both the community standard way to handle testing and the most flexible as well as, imo having the best overall development experience.

If you want to change how the tests execute in your own application, you are of course free to do so but I am betting after some time working with it that way you will find it to be more cumbersome than beneficial.

* **What is the current behavior?**
Not your fault, but doesn't work under WSL bash because `node-macaddress` makes an as-yet unsupported system call to `os.networkInterfaces()`:

> ERROR in ./~/css-loader!./src/app/app.component.css
> Module build failed: Error: EINVAL: invalid argument, uv_interface_addresses
>     at Error (native)
>     at Object.lib.networkInterfaces (/mnt/c/projects/angular2-webpack-starter/node_modules/macaddress/index.js:31:21)

>         └── macaddress@0.2.9  (git://github.com/thebeastofcaerbannog/node-macaddress.git#43238cd0569573837d4b48a27b3063d287d2968b)

bug report
report a *bug* After typescript 2.0.6 the build process stuck at loading js. No debug error happens but seems infinite burning CPU.

Stuck point: 

Project is running at http://localhost:8888/
webpack output is served from /
Content not from webpack is served from xxxxxxxx
404s will fallback to /index.html                                                                                                67% building modules 1165/1226 modules 61 active ...

No debug log and nothing different to verbose mode.
I also switch between node from 7.2.1 to 6.9.2 nothing changed.
The stuck point is building a module that if I remove that module it stuck to another one. so something general must be wrong during the module js file loading.


Solution is to fix the typescript version to 2.0.6 instead of ^2.0.6

I´d like to add some missing sentences in the wiki topic "How to include jQuery":

1.) Use the following import to include JQuery: import * as jQuery from 'jquery';
2.) Put the ProvidePlugin into the file webpack.common.js

This is a generally thing in my opinion: The 2 sentences are understandable clear to everone who is "into it". But for me it took some "time`n google" to find it out.
Please, create a [PR](https://help.github.com/articles/creating-a-pull-request/) with your desired changes.

* **What kind of change does this PR introduce?** (Bug fix, feature, docs update, ...)
1. per #1265 Nitrous is no longer available. I have removed it and added a deploy section that includes Netlify. 

2. Added a [Netlify button](https://www.netlify.com/blog/2016/11/29/introducing-the-deploy-to-netlify-button/) for easy deployment

* **Other information**:

When you click on a “Deploy to Netlify” button, you’ll be redirected to Netlify’s direct deploy page. There you’ll be able to create a new site based on the template you were looking at. While this is happening. Netlify also creates a new GitHub repo for the new site. The best way to understand how this works is to see it in action, try it out:

[![Deploy to Netlify](https://www.netlify.com/img/deploy/button.svg)](https://app.netlify.com/start/deploy?repository=https://github.com/AngularClass/angular2-webpack-starter)

TypeScript is pinned in master to the latest working version. Keeping this issue open until we can pick up a `2.1.4` compliant version of `awesome-typescript-loader`

After googling this for a bit, I found this: https://github.com/s-panferov/awesome-typescript-loader/issues/190 - for me, clearing cache and changing package.json's typescript dependency from "^2.0.6" to "2.0.10" worked. The app builds and runs now.

In addition to @d3viant0ne 's [commit](https://github.com/AngularClass/angular2-webpack-starter/commit/6193e308f29c82f3cbda4395f487a111a10f7e48#diff-b9cfc7f2cdf78a7f4b91a753d10865a2) of 9-Dec, I had to set `"@angular/forms": "2.2.1"` (use to be `^2.2.1`, which brought me `v2.3.0`). As I forked `angular2-webpack-starter` before [that commit](https://github.com/AngularClass/angular2-webpack-starter/commit/306672798cf5865037ccba37ac7aa4feb89c2110#diff-b9cfc7f2cdf78a7f4b91a753d10865a2) of 23-Nov, it was `^2.2.1` just for the `@angular/forms`.

So my full fix was:

1. Modified `package.json` to set:

- `"typescript": "2.1.1"` (use to be `^2.0.6`, which brought me `v2.1.4`)
- `"@angular/forms": "2.2.1"` (use to be `^2.2.1`, which brought me `v2.3.0`, when other `@angular/` were `2.2.1`). As an alternative, you can make them all `^2.2.1` and it will work again as all `@angular/` versions will be aligned.

2. Deleted corresponding folders in `node_modules` and ran `npm install`. For some reason, running `npm install` straight away didn't work (something was cached?).

Can confirm, modifiying my `package.json` to `"typescript": "2.1.1"` resolved the issue. I'm using `"awesome-typescript-loader": "2.2.4"` for my angular 2.3.0 project.

After modifying the `package.json`, I deleted the node_modules folder then ran `npm cache clean` and finally `npm install`. All is working fine now.

It worked for me by pinning typescript to `2.1.1` in `package.json` with node `5.6.0` and npm `3.6.0`.

change typescript version to 2.1.1 or 2.0.10 in package.json.

Now I see the file name remains unchanged if only main script has been edited.
However I see cloudflare/browser cache is causing issues, I do not know why. Maybe file remains the same but content is different?

I'm thinking to change to random file name anyway so that no cache will be used.

As far as I remember in production build vendor name is appended file hash, so that should help in that case. Dev builds should not be run on productions, as they lack the glory of tree shaking and uglification.

This behavior is produced by WebpackMd5Hash plugin.

@naivefun - There are quite a few ways to implement cache busting. I personally roll with something like this but I also have a moderately complex caching setup between my app, docker containers & nginx.

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

Point being, this is one of those things that is really dependent on exactly what you are trying to achieve and how you are setup. Any way it goes, you will need `WebpackMd5Hash` as @karolmie1  mentioned.

It's also worth noting that what I run in production isn't based off the starter, so just grabbing that snippet isn't going to work ( just an example ).

I highly suggest reading https://webpack.js.org/guides/caching/ more than once and then start hacking on your project. Caching is one of those things you can get "kind of right" and end up with weird results.  

You are going to want to understand your own caching implementation completely as it pertains to your app & the deployment stack it is running on. Docs + Trial and error is the best way to get there imo.

Depending on how your CI / CD workflow is setup, your deployment stacks should be pretty close to identical thus your issues shouldn't be environmental. A really good tool for this would be docker.

The point of a production build outside of obfuscating your code ( if you choose to ) is really to reduce your payload as much as is humanly possible to limit the amount of .js / .css a user has to download to view your application. Uglify usually takes care of this. What you end up with it a gigantic block of truncated function & variable names, which is in general a real pain to debug. 

Some modern browsers have gotten smart enough to only make the http call to grab sourcemaps if you open the dev tools but some older browser version will simply pull them down, increasing your payload ( considerably ).

Point being, you really shouldn't have to debug a production deployment. The goal should be to catch issues like that in your deployment workflow. How you do really depends on your team / infrastructure.

Some people run a staging stack and do blue / green deployments with a sourcemap enabled build. I have seen others who don't want or need to go that far run a `production like` build to a QA stack with sourcemaps enabled.

I was a DevOps engineer before switching to frontend dev, if you want to have a more in depth discussion about a workable CI/CD workflow you can find me in the AngularClass slack channel.

Per https://github.com/AngularClass/angular2-webpack-starter/commit/5db20a697bee643758ce597c8b9f7059f398e462#commitcomment-20016692
See https://github.com/yarnpkg/yarn/issues/1583 that is a bad idea, when it comes to really use `yarn`.

@katallaxie - The yarn.lock was removed by @gdi2290. The ignore for yarn is also at his request.

It has also been removed from the travis build. There is no need for yarn in the base seed, if people want to use it in their personal projects adding it is simple.

@d3viant0ne Yeah It is really bad idea. yarn.lock is like one of the most important reasons to use yarn. 
I very often had this problem - I've downloaded old repo from github and I started to fire it up, but I couldn't manage to get it working, because author used older version of npm packages and the project won't compile anymore. (this also happend to me on material2 branch here if I remember correctly)

yarn.lock is essential to not allow this to happen.

It may make pull requests and diffs ugly though.
Worry not, there is better solution than to remove it altogeter!

.gitattributes:
yarn.lock -diff

yarn.lock will be treated as binary from now on, won't be shown in difs and counted in lines changed if you care about such statistics.
@d3viant0ne yep! you can remove it, but you should not `.gitignore` it, as people really use it in their projects.

@katallaxie I will create a pull request with .gitattributes solution in a moment, you can check if you like it.

Damn, it works in local console, but it does not work on github, and there is no way to make it work :(
yeah I didn't see that with yarn. let's just keep it out of the initial repo

ok I got it!!!
just to know, I've modified the port number at line 26 of https://github.com/AngularClass/angular2-webpack-starter/blob/master/config/webpack.prod.js 
from
` line26: const PORT = process.env.PORT || 8080;`
to
`line26: const PORT = process.env.PORT || 80;`

After that I've build with
`npm run build:prod`

and copied and paste /dist folder to the root of my apache web server.

It works.

        },

Hi,
could you tell me how to load component templates from external url? 
I have removed `angular2-template-loader` from webpack.common.js but then I'm stuck.

Let's say I am hosting my (MVC) website at `localhost/MyWebsite `and I set: `<base href="/MyWebsite/">` on the page hosting angular app.

I try load the template using `templateUrl: "/templates/app.component.html"` but the request goes to `"localhost/templates/app.component.html"` instead of `"localhost/MyWebsite/templates/app.component.html"`

How to make angular respect  `<base href="/MyWebsite/">` ?

* **Do you want to request a *feature* or report a *bug*?**
*feature*


* **What is the current behavior?**
css is inlined in bundle. 
would like to be able to directly edit css files through the broweser - with Chrome's workspace feature.
(would probably need source maps from inline styling to css files in src/)


* **What is the expected behavior?**
editing CSS on Chrome browser with configured workspace would change local files permanently in src/ directory.

This is how the browser style pane look now, the style is inline and not as part of any file :
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6062662/20639632/8b46dea0-b3d1-11e6-827d-34d4bf8d7a49.png)


* **What is the motivation / use case for changing the behavior?**
Editing CSS directly save a LOT of time - when changes reflect immediately in the browser and saved to the source files.
As a designer, I try different style options (eg. border weight/color) until I find the right one. When I do, the best thing would be if it would be saved in the source files.

So far, this is the only thing keeping me off from using Angular 2.

Latest AngularClass repo version.

with Workspace support

* **What kind of change does this PR introduce?** (Bug fix, feature, docs update, ...)
Build Pipeline Fixes & Improvements


* **What is the current behavior?** (You can also link to an open issue here)
There are numerous issues with the current CI pipeline. Outside the fact that it currently just doesn't work, the time to feedback to the developer is a bit excessive and we don't cover enough of the tooling in out CI runs.


* **What is the new behavior (if this is a feature change)?**

- [x] Fixes issues with TSLint.
     - Codelizer doesn't yet support Tslint 4.x the peerDep fails builds on Node 4.x
- [x] Fixes style issues merged while linting was broken.
- [x] Removes yarn from the travis build ( this loses us time not saves it ).
- [x] Updates to Trusty from Precise.
     - The Trusty container comes with Chrome installed & configured
- [x] Removes the docker build as we aren't doing anything with it thus costing us more time.
- [x] Updates Protractor version.
- [x] Executes e2e tests in Travis against production build for slightly better tooling coverage.
     - Adds a `server:prod:ci` script to run http-server on port 3000. Local development e2e tasks are uneffected

* **Other information**:

Temporarily sets node 4.x to `allow_failures` due to an issue in the `LazyParseWebpackPlugin` on nodejs 4.x running on Ubuntu. Issue link is in the Travis config.

Resolves #1113
Resolves #1197
Resolves #1192
Resolves #1189

* **What kind of change does this PR introduce?** (Bug fix, feature, docs update, ...)
Workaround for bug outlined in #1188 

* **Other information**:
Further investigation required for the behavioral change between `use:` & `loader:` in `webpack.config.js`

@maxx0r  @d3viant0ne
Angular Material integration is quite straight forward.

Saying that, if you are using bootstrap loader and saas loader like, it's very easy to include material scss.

in **.bootstraprc** add the below line.

`appStyles: PATH_TO_YOUR_APPLICATION_SCSS`

and in your **APPLICATION_SCSS** add the material theme imports. You can use any theme here.

`@import '~@angular/material/core/theming/prebuilt/pink-bluegrey.scss';`

But I am wondering, is there any way to choose the themes dynamically?

@ebeal - Pull the trigger. Maintaining that branch given how little effort is actually needed to enable Material2 is just silly.

The recommended way now is to use the postcss common loader syntax. Which is to make a new file called `postcss.config.js` in the root of your project and put all postcss related plugins there.

You can find more info on the [postcss-loader](https://github.com/postcss/postcss-loader) github page.

There are a few caveats, I found this issue quite useful:
https://github.com/postcss/postcss-loader/issues/127

* **What kind of change does this PR introduce?** (Bug fix, feature, docs update, ...)
Fix a bug that appears with Angular2.2 when using a production bundle.

* **What is the current behavior?** (You can also link to an open issue here)
Currently, when launching a prod bundle, the app doesn't work because of an `Cannot convert undefined or null to Object` that occurs in the `disableDebugInfo` function of Angular2.2.
This function tries to delete `window.ng.provider`, but at the moment of the call of the `disabledDebugInfo` function, the `ng` property has not yet been created in the `window` object because Angular is not yet initialized.

* **What is the new behavior (if this is a feature change)?**
We now wait for Angular to be initialized before disabling debug info and enabling production mode.
This way, the `disableDebugInfo` call succeed and the app doesn't crash anymore.

* **Other information**:

I don't understand the purpose behind `AppState` (app.service.ts). Is this intended to store additional state for `AppComponent` (in other words a sort of store what `AppComponent` may need to share) or is it more a generic store for all components of the application?

I am leaning more towards just a shared, non-reactive service to store & share state.

What are the use cases of `AppState`? Storing the currently authenticated user?

Rolling the state back up the tree to a `single source of truth` prevents you from mutating shared state which will have unintended / undesired side effects in your application that are extremely difficult to run down in a large application. In short, you want as many dumb components as is humanly possible.

What Patrick implemented is very similar to `ngrx` in a lot of ways. For instance if you look  [here](https://github.com/AngularClass/angular2-webpack-starter/blob/master/src/app/app.service.ts#L19-L22) this implementation attempts to prevent people from mutating state directly, leading to the issue described above.

Inevitably you will need to maintain state in your application and inevitably you will need your applications components to communicate. Angular2 is designed to flow data / state down and events up. Your lower level components simply take `@Input()` & `@Output()` which makes them reusable and easier to maintain / test. As your application grows, this approach also makes it much easier to reason about your application state given you always know the beginning and end of every state change.

As an aside, this implementation is also very simple to convert to use something like `ngrx` should you or your team decide you want to leverage that particular suite of tools.

We spoke via email and gave a preview of our current progress (which one course will be out soon) and issued a refund.

Quality takes time. While starting the courses in the Master Bundle We realized the community was missing a ton of advanced content. This meant that we either would need to cover advanced topics within each course or start releasing our separate content to reference. A good example of this is our current Fundamentals course which skips a lot of the conceptual topics since there's a ton of content already out there already. We provide a guided path of how to build an app in the real world. Following this teaching style we quickly realized all of the courses within the Master Bundle requires knowledge of advanced patterns which aren't covered anywhere online. We decided that we would have to create advanced content so we have something to point to as references. We started by creating a Router course and an Advanced Components courses only to combine them into one course as Advanced course to cover more content. Right now anyone who bought the Master Bundle gets everything for free until we finish the courses. So that means everyone will get the complete path to becoming an expert at Angular 2. This is different from content release right now which doesn't provide a path because it simply takes more thought to create. We're also providing real-world advanced patterns seen in large Angular 2 apps in production. Also, the introduction of NgModule dramatically changed the way we should be architecting our applications so previously we had a great plan and progression on how to guide users to becoming experts. After NgModule we first had to figure out new patterns that developers should be doing and figuring out the correct approach. Because of that huge change we had to regroup and delay the release. If you followed our Fundamentals course then you would know that it was right before NgModule

* **What kind of change does this PR introduce?** (Bug fix, feature, docs update, ...)
Fixes #1161


* **What is the current behavior?** (You can also link to an open issue here)
TSLint fails, breaking Karma tests.


* **What is the new behavior (if this is a feature change)?**
TSLint runs, allowing Karma tests to run.


* **Other information**:
Deprecated configuration options were breaking Karma tests
Would not be necessary if pull request #1105 is approved.

closes https://github.com/AngularClass/angular2-webpack-starter/issues/1113

* **What kind of change does this PR introduce?** (Bug fix, feature, docs update, ...)
This is a bug fix; it removes a dependency, and changes e2e tests to use imported functions instead of ambient functions.


* **What is the current behavior?** (You can also link to an open issue here)
Definitions are conflicting and the e2e tests fail to run.  (https://github.com/AngularClass/angular2-webpack-starter/issues/1113)

* **What is the new behavior (if this is a feature change)?**
This change uses bundled typescript definitions from the `protractor` module instead of downloading duplicates through `@types/protractor`.


* **Other information**:
`npm run e2e` to test.
This fails CI due to `Chrome version must be >= 53.0.2785.0`, you'll have to update Chrome for the build to succeed.

Hello guys, 
Thank you for the wonderful starter project! 

It would be really great if you could help me with the following issue, as it can cause a lot of troubles on a real production environment. 
The issue is with long-term caching of static assets and lazy loaded modules.
Reproducible on windows and Linux machines. Here are the steps:
1. clone the repository, run `npm install` and `npm run build:prod`
2. copy dist folder and save it somewhere to be able to compare old content with newly generated later
3. modify Lazy-loaded component (src\app+detail\detail.component.ts) somehow (change console.log statement for instance). 
4. run `npm run build:prod` again
5. compare folders with any diff tool. Here are my results

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/13537012/19752979/f13e4638-9c09-11e6-899a-9cb8c6a6a3cc.png)

The only difference is in polyfills commons chunk:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/13537012/19753039/78170fdc-9c0a-11e6-8fd6-82ab954cdf0d.png)

For some reason, chunkhash for polyfills chunk is not changed although content is different. 

Appreciate any help.
BTW looks similar to  webpack/webpack#1155.
@ilyahumbar if you do not add anything different to the polyfills, which usually you don't. The hash will not be different, as the content did not vary.

When looking at the dependency tree .. Codecov is using an ancient lib which is where your checksum issues are coming from. That said, `angular2-template-loader` shouldn't be leaking devDeps in a package. Already spoke to Sean about it, I'll be adding a bit of packaging to the template loader lib to tighten up what is being pulled down when it's installed.

Just bumped into this as well as I was working on upgrading from 5.0.5.

Source maps WERE working.

I finally found a way to fix this.

First of all. The problem why it was occurring was due to this line in the sassLoader

`result.map.sources[0] = path.relative(self.options.context, resourcePath);`

Here, the following object was always null.

> self.opitons.context

Even if I passed the context in Webpack.common.config, it was still null.

So finally, correct way of doing is,

Add the following in the respective config files and not the webpack.common.config

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

> Give output path as `./` not your actual output folder. I don't what is the reason. But that doesn't work.

Damn typos, is `output`, not `outupt`, now the error says:
<S_CODE_TOKEN>

It seems i have misconfigured the `resolve-url-loader` or the `file-loader` for png's files when importing primeng.

Hello lovely humans, [copy-webpack-plugin](https://www.npmjs.com/package/copy-webpack-plugin) just published its new version 4.0.0.
State Update :rocket:
Dependency copy-webpack-plugin
New version 4.0.0
Type devDependency
This version is **not covered** by your **current version range**. Without accepting this pull request your project will work just like it did before. There might be a bunch of new features, fixes and perf improvements that the maintainers worked on for you though. I recommend you look into these changes and try to get onto the latest version of copy-webpack-plugin. Given that you have a decent test suite, a passing build is a strong indicator that you can take advantage of these changes by merging the proposed change into your project. Otherwise this branch is a great starting point for you to work on the update. Do you have any ideas how I could improve these pull requests? Did I report anything you think isn’t right? Are you unsure about how things are supposed to work? There is a collection of [frequently asked questions](https://greenkeeper.io/faq.html) and while I’m just a bot, there is a group of people who are happy to teach me new things. [Let them know](https://github.com/greenkeeperio/greenkeeper/issues/new). Good luck with your project :sparkles: You rock! :palm_tree: --- [GitHub Release](https://github.com/kevlened/copy-webpack-plugin/releases/tag/v4.0.0)

This is a rewrite to add several new features.

Features

  • Debug mode can be enabled with 3 options: warning (default), info, or debug.
  • Transform method can modify the contents of a file before writing it.
  • Warn on missing file or directory. Use the NoErrorsPlugin if you want this to fail the build.
  • Allow name templates in to paths, like webpack's file-loader.
  • Improved performance by reading files concurrently. Before, we used Bluebird's each() to process files, now we use map(). The concurrency option is exposed if you'd like to override the default of 100 parallel files.

Bug fixes

  • Allow graceful-fs to patch EMFILE/ENFILE issues. fs.readFileSync isn't used to load file contents into webpack's compilation.assets anymore.
  • Handle edge case for webpack-dev-server where absolute to couldn't be written.

Breaking changes

  • Ignore globs also ignore dotted files by default.
--- The new version differs by 14 commits . - [`1423818`](https://github.com/kevlened/copy-webpack-plugin/commit/1423818cb3f550854531a98625c985ecefe9c75f) 4.0.0 (#83) - [`03c798b`](https://github.com/kevlened/copy-webpack-plugin/commit/03c798bec7f6f4422dd9e6fbae405c896224007f) Changed default concurrency to 100 for EMFILE/ENFILE issues (#82) - [`900b8d5`](https://github.com/kevlened/copy-webpack-plugin/commit/900b8d51a29033616a7fa90ffcc9658d09875603) Removed CHANGELOG.md in favor of releases tab (#81) - [`9f1059f`](https://github.com/kevlened/copy-webpack-plugin/commit/9f1059f7f463a7d19f4df89fde418811e37feabd) Changed default ignore glob to ignore dot files (#80) - [`323b1d7`](https://github.com/kevlened/copy-webpack-plugin/commit/323b1d74ef35ed2221637d8028b1bef854deb523) Improved docs and handle dev-server edge case (#78) - [`8531cbd`](https://github.com/kevlened/copy-webpack-plugin/commit/8531cbdcc6d5de2d840008b7cd4ae9810618de02) Added transform method to patterns (#77) - [`32eed14`](https://github.com/kevlened/copy-webpack-plugin/commit/32eed14a0cc3e3fc97ea183647177b7ba53edd88) Added name templates and improved performance (#76) - [`7d7a3d8`](https://github.com/kevlened/copy-webpack-plugin/commit/7d7a3d8a899c9825b57336a80e57139fd0d9fb7d) Rewrote with debug mode and warn on missing file or dir (#74) - - **Do you want to request a _feature_ or report a _bug_?**
  Feature Request
- **What is the current behavior?**
  Import statements in entry points for CSS and SASS are not currently working,
- **What is the expected behavior?**
  Adding an Import statement in any of the entry points (IE Vendor) for a SASS (.scss) or a CSS (.css) file should result in that stylesheet being bundled into the global css for the application.
- **What is the motivation / use case for changing the behavior?**
  Some modules, such as Bootstrap V4, require stylesheets to be imported into the application to enable certain features, such as the flex grid. There are current workarounds in place, but they are bulky and bloated. This method of importing stylesheets used to work in the original builds of this seed project.\*

Using the following loaders in the mean time, no guarantee they will work in everyone's case, but they provide the temporary fix until we can get some vetted support for this.

For all those in this thread, the proposed solution is outline in the PR #1304 from @colinskow. If you want a say in how this is implemented, now would be the time to do so. If nobody objects, i'll be landing that by e.o.d
#1304 Does not provide the loader for SASS files in test environments. Other than that, the PR takes care of the issue in the current version of the repo.
Generally Karma doesn't need external stylesheets, and unit tests probably shouldn't be dependent on them. So I purposely left it out of the test config. Tests will launch faster.
Unit test definitely shouldn't be dependent on style sheets any more than they should depend on data. @colinskow is correct in his test implementation.

Karma will not launch without error unless I add a null loader for SASS in my environment. The purpose is not to incorporate them but to ensure that the file types will be handled appropriately when encountered.

Went as far as deleting my development vagrant VM and starting over. Here is what worked for me:

Increase VM memory and use NFS shared folder. Details can be found here https://stefanwrobel.com/how-to-make-vagrant-performance-not-suck.

Increasing the amount of inotify watchers (https://github.com/guard/listen/wiki/Increasing-the-amount-of-inotify-watchers):
`echo fs.inotify.max_user_watches=524288 | sudo tee -a /etc/sysctl.conf ; sudo sysctl -p`

Then I still had remnants of previous failures probably, because I had to do an npm cache clean as well.

Seems to work well now. :)

Seems to be related with protractor updating to work with TS2.

Got e2e tests running again by updating the following:

`"@types/selenium-webdriver": "2.53.33",`
`"protractor": "4.0.10",`

and removed:

`"@types/protractor": "^1.5.20",`

also don't forget to remove `"protractor",` from tsconfig `compoilerOptions` as well:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

(since protractor comes with their own typings now).

And next add the required imports to *.e2e.ts files like ([ref](https://github.com/angular/protractor/tree/master/exampleTypescript)):

`import { browser, by } from 'protractor';`

just a small note: in the import, add "element", like this:
import { browser, by, element } from 'protractor';
Thanks @svieillard and @mdelgadov. I put in a PR to fix this on master.
To fix this error with  "protractor": "^4.0.14" I needed to also remove @types/selenium-webdriver as protractor now includes these types also

Looking at the current state of the repo some changed were made the broke the github pages feature.

For example, the `metadata` property on the config object is now gone and it's part of the `HtmlWebpackPlugin`, we need it so we know the `baseUrl`.

The `output.publicPath` is also gone (webpack updates) which is also important for url purposes.

I will take a look and refactor it

@katallaxie , it looks like [this commit](https://github.com/AngularClass/angular2-webpack-starter/commit/7bfba744ebfa77c5dfb30524e639e394a1d92c0e#diff-f737fedb5357468044db2dbe98eb0218L39) moved the `metadata` property from the root of the config object into the  `HtmlWebpackPlugin` in `webpack.common.js` however other features relay on it for useful information (i.e: it's not only for the HtmlWebpackPlugin). Github pages is one but also [webpack.dev.js#23](https://github.com/AngularClass/angular2-webpack-starter/blob/master/config/webpack.dev.js#L23)  and [webpack.prod.js#27](https://github.com/AngularClass/angular2-webpack-starter/blob/master/config/webpack.prod.js#L27) assume it's there.

I will duplicate the `metadata` property in `webpack.common.js` to be both on root object and in `HtmlWebpackPlugin` for now to restore order.

However, some refactoring is needed since the logical process is wrong.
`HtmlWebpackPlugin` is set in `webpack.common.js` but a user might want to alter some values in dev/prod... 

It's not for this topic but I think common should have a pre process callback that can get the (almost) final config object and do some work such as adding plugins etc using updated/final objects.

I think an issue is needed for this, for now I will just duplicate to restore github pages functionality.

Here's a great example of why we need to pre process in common.

The GitHub pages feature requires some changes in the `HtmlWebpackPlugin.
Since GitHub pages sites have a URL path prefixed with the repo's name it must be set as the base url (e.g: angularclass.github.io/**angular2-webpack-starter**). Most (if not all) projects does not care about GitHub pages so the configuration is usually set so the app is in the domain's root (e.g: www.example.com/).

the GitHub pages feature must be transparent so it need to be able to set the configuration values of `HtmlWebpackPlugin` which is not possible (cleanly) at the moment.

OK, issue fixed without changing `webpack.common.js`
However, relaying on HtmlWebpackPlugin API 

Also added a workaround for a bug in GH Pages after their move to Jekyll 3.3, this workaround must be reverted by people who use Jekyll in their GH pages.
@katallaxie please review before I merge.

I am using devtool: cheap-module-source-map in my dev build as mentioned in this project. 

Every time I deploy the app to aws, it requires me to do CTRL+F5(full cache refresh) on the browser and it does not pull latest changes on normal page refresh (F5). Is there any way to refresh the cache on F5 as users might not do CTRL+F5 in prod and will have issues.

The browser caches resources by default; also the HTTP Server sends information regarding the caching behavior in the browser. You should version your resources `?v=12345`, so that the browser fetches the most recent version and does not caches. Btw. you should allow to cache things, it's a better UX.

- **What kind of change does this PR introduce?** (Bug fix, feature, docs update, ...)
  Bug fix
- **What is the current behavior?** (You can also link to an open issue here)
  #1070 humans.txt and robots.txt get copied from the assets directory to the output assets directory.
- **What is the new behavior (if this is a feature change)?**
  All files in the assets folder get copied to dist/assets except for humans.txt and robots.txt.
  humans.txt and robots.txt get copied from the assets folder to the root dist/ folder.
- **Other information**:

Fixes issue #1070

The standard for humans.txt and robots.txt says that they should be available from the root of the application. This change will make sure that they get copied from the assets folder to the dist/ root instead of to dist/assets.

In the future, if we need to add any more files that get copied to root, it would probably be a lot easier to make a new directory in the assets directory for all of them and just copy the contents instead of individual files.

  removed ignored `density` attribute from manifest.json
- **What is the current behavior?** (You can also link to an open issue here)
  ignored attribute `density` is present in `manifest.json`

  attribute `density` is removed from manifest.json
- **Other information**:
  According to [Google](https://developers.google.com/web/updates/2014/11/Support-for-installable-web-apps-with-webapp-manifest-in-chrome-38-for-Android), `density` will be ignored from manifest.json:

> Please note, there used to be a dedicated “density” field in the manifest spec, this has been removed from the Spec and the implementation in Chrome. If it is defined in your manifest it will be ignored.  

Also, there is no information about `density` in the [spec](https://w3c.github.io/manifest/).

Here's how I got Sass working with Hot Module Replacement in my app. 
- In dev mode, Hot Module Replacement is enabled for Sass
- In production mode, all styles are extracted into an external .css file - to prevent "flash" of unstyled content and allow caching of css.

My loader for SCSS - works fast and easy

<S_CODE_TOKEN>
- `sass-vars-loader` allows you to load a JS file with exported variables, then import them into every scss file.
- `sass-resources` loads up a specified array of .scss files, and prepends them before every .scss file is compiled. Useful for appwide variables and mixins.
- `postcss` allows you to do lots of cool stuff, like autoprefix classes with vendor prefixes.

Here's how to specify the options for each of those loaders

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

This is where `sassVarsConfig` is defined:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

Here's how to setup the `sass-js-variables.js`

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

Lastly, instead of using angular2's `styleUrls` or `styles` properties of the @Component decorator, I opt to do it like this instead:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

I import the scss outside of the @Component decorator. Why? Because this way I get Hot Module Replacement to work on my .scss files, and it allows my styles to apply globally. I then simply namespace my .scss files with the selector for each specific component, which creates an encapsulated style to prevent it from affecting other components:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

That's it.  [Here's my repo](https://github.com/IAMtheIAM/angular2-webpack2-dotnet-starter) which is a fork of this repo, that shows all this off in action. (Note: its using .NET core to host the app, so you'll need .NET Core SDK installed in order to run it)

Report a bug
- **What is the current behavior?**

Module paths with import { Something } from 'custom_modules/things';
Cannot be resolved with webpack as the module cannot be resolved. 
- **If the current behavior is a bug, please provide the steps to reproduce and if possible a minimal demo of the problem** via
  https://plnkr.co or similar (you can use this template as a starting point: http://plnkr.co/edit/tpl:AvJOMERrnz94ekVua0u5).

Import any module with the module method. I.e. Not absolute or relative paths.
- **What is the expected behavior?**

Webpack should resolve module based imports.
- **What is the motivation / use case for changing the behavior?**

It is a part of webpack that is supported, yet the config does not work with.

- Angular version: 2.0.0-beta.X
- Browser: [all | Chrome XX | Firefox XX | IE XX | Safari XX | Mobile Chrome XX | Android X.X Web Browser | iOS XX Safari | iOS XX UIWebView | iOS XX WKWebView ]

This can be fixed by changing the resolve: area in webpack.common.js from using root: and modulesDirectories to just using the new config option 'modules' This is the new way for webpack 2.0 that package.json now points to.

modules: [
        helpers.root('src'),
        "node_modules"
]

Hi, 

I was wondering what the preloader on .ts files to use the `string-replace-loader` would be used for in a project.  I'm not an expert in javascript/the module ecosystem by any means, but this is what I think that part does:
- node, commonjs, amd, systemjs all have different ways that they resolve/import javascript modules
- this checks your code in case you have a module that is targeted toward a systemjs runtime (I'm shaky on what this actually entails/if you can use it in tandem with other types of modules)
- it replaces the `import` to import the module then does..... something.

I'd appreciate if anyone could clarify this.  If this is more suited to StackOverflow or a Slack channel somewhere, please let me know and I will close this issue.

fixing the version of @types/selenium-webdriver resolves the issue

`"@types/selenium-webdriver": "2.44.26"`
@kislovskij Thanks, solved my problem.
Same here with `"@types/selenium-webdriver": "2.53.33"`

Putting `"@types/selenium-webdriver": "2.44.29"` in your package.json is the latest version that does not display the error

Note: Make sure that you do not have a Caret `^` before the version number as that will cause npm to install Version the latest matching minor version which is: `"2.53.33"`.  As described above will cause this error to occur.

This is more of a general question on git + Angular2 development practice with this starter. How should one keep angular2-webpack-starter code up to date when you start commiting your own app code to pulled repository? I've never used a 'starter' code before from another repository to build my app on top of it so I'm wondering how to keep commiting your own app code and keep pulling all new updates of angular2-webpack-starter's code?

I just completed doing this recently. Our app code had deviated quite a way before we started upgrading so merging was going to be too much of a pain. We basically just wanted to get updates to the webpack build setup, not so much with the actual app code. It was time consuming but I ended up just walking through the commit history to `master`, and either cherry-picking or re-implementing any relevant changes.

I use  Beyond Compare to compare both repos (compare by folders), it nicely tells me what are the differences and just manually merge the diffs into my repo and commit. I have been doing this for months now.

I'm currently doing this successfully for several projects this way:
1. Clone this repo
2. Change the origin to your own git repo
3. Add angularclass origin `git remote add angularclass https://github.com/AngularClass/angular2-webpack-starter.git`
4. Fetch/Merge angularclass/master into your project as updates come in.
5. Profit

I am getting this error also. Fresh git clone and the same problem. I think it has to do with the change in the latest Webpack 2.1 beta. It seems that Master is using beta.21, which should be fine. Beta 23 has the breaking changes. I am going to try Beta 22 as that has fixed some issues for me with some other apps.

@arifhussain353 I fixed the problem by removing my node_modules install, then changing the Webpack dependencies in package.json to:

`"webpack": "2.1.0-beta.22",`
`"webpack-dev-middleware": "^1.8.1",`
`"webpack-dev-server": "2.1.0-beta.4",`

Then `npm start` and everything works.
@jwuliger  Hi, Thank you very much it solved my problem :) :+1:

- **I'm submitting a ...**
  [ ] bug report
  [ ] feature request
  [x ] question about the decisions made in the repository

The readme states "We use the component approach in our starter. This is the new standard for developing Angular apps and a great way to ensure maintainable code by encapsulation of our behavior logic."

However, RC6 removed @Component.directives (deprecated in a previous RC) which indicates to me that the angular team is supporting a module pattern. it doesn't really make sense to add a bunch of declarations in your `app.module.ts` that won't be used by the entire app, but only by specific components. this might be a weak example, but `home` uses the `x-large` directive but `about` may never need to have the ability to use that directive.

Does this make sense or am I misunderstanding the Angular team's intentions?

I think the README means as the overall architecture of a web app as explained here: http://developer.telerik.com/featured/front-end-application-frameworks-component-architectures/.

This is different from NgModule, which  is to bundle parts of your application

Well, regardless of what the README refers to, my question is about switching to a pattern that uses NgModule more heavily.

Instead of having app module declare home component and x-large directive, using a module pattern there would be an app module and a home module. The home module would have declarations for the home component and x-large directive.

@gaurav2887 Update the webpack.*.js files to match the new format. There is a migration example at the end of the beta.23 release notes that may help with that: https://github.com/webpack/webpack/releases

Using one of the new configuration option specified in the schema also solves the problem. For instance _modulesDirectories_ has changed to simply _modules_ in the later betas. [Webpack issue #3018](https://github.com/webpack/webpack/issues/3018) has an interesting discussion around whether this should have been made a breaking change.

- **What kind of change does this PR introduce?** (Bug fix, feature, docs update, ...)
  Prevents breakage from the latest webpack beta versions (2.1.0-beta.22 and up)

2.1.0-beta.22 works for me , 2.1.0-beta.22 is broken
beta.24 has already been tagged which includes a fix for the validations issue.

I don't think we should pin the older webpack's version. Instead we should make fixes to fit the new webpack's requirements. Here are migration examples:
1. [beta.22 => beta.23 breaking changes](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/pull/2237/files#diff-427f56af65fe1d070dcca914a7f884d6L19)
2. [Other updates](https://github.com/webpack/webpack.js.org/blob/develop/content/how-to/upgrade-from-webpack-1.md#moduleloaders-is-now-modulerules)
3. [Discussion](https://github.com/webpack/webpack/issues/3018)

Hi @randyangeles,

If you are trying to setup routes you need to provide the routes in your import and unless I am mistaken importing RouterTestingModule takes care of mocking Router for you.  You would need to do something like the following:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

You can then create routes to actual or mock components within your test.  In my case the routing is really simple (I really only use routing to make it easy to get info from the URL and for future support) so I actually removed the routing and only include the core import at the moment.

Take a look at the documentation (which unfortunately still appears to be a work in progress) for more information (https://angular.io/docs/ts/latest/api/router/testing/index/RouterTestingModule-class.html).

Hope this helps!

Hi @gaurav2887,

Just saw your post.  As I mentioned to @randyangeles, I don't think you should be mocking the router rather use the withRoutes function when importing RouterTestingModule.  That way you can route to either your actual components or to mock components.  My hope is that using this approach we will be less susceptible to framework changes going forward.

Hope that helps!

Hi @eamell,

Tried your approach and it worked! Going to leave what I did here to help someone down the road hopefully.

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

Had to make the router public in AppComponent to be able to spy on it (not sure if that's best practice). Thanks for your help!

Hey, I had this issue too using WebStorm. The problem is that the `lib` option doesn't seem to be supported (see [this issue](https://github.com/TypeStrong/atom-typescript/issues/1009)). What I did was remove the `lib` option and put `core-js` inside the `types` option. My tsconfig file looks like this:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>
