Resolving: no longer relevant

@d3viant0ne how is this no longer relevant? I'll be honest I'm not using angular2-webpack-starter but I am seeing this error and the plugin solution has worked well for me (though it seemed like a hack). Is this resolved in a better way now? I just pulled all the latest modules from npm.

Using the ContextReplacementPlugin hack causes webpack to start watching the folder you pass to it for any changes. So if __dirname is your project root it will watch any file in your project for changes it seems. 
This triggered insane amount of rebuilds for me because it startet to rebuild on any change in the .git folder.

A version of this error will surface when upgrading to Angular 4.0.0-rc.1.

> WARNING in ./~/@angular/core/@angular/core.es5.js 3702:272-293 Critical dependency: the request of a dependency is an expression 

This change in webpack.common.js resolved the issue for me. Credit to Martin Wegner here [https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/11580](url)

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

@d3viant0ne This seems still relevant. I'm getting this now, and its over 6 months since reported.
This issue is caused by webpack being unhappy with dynamic imports. The Webpack team states that this is by design:
https://github.com/webpack/webpack-dev-server/issues/212#issuecomment-242449586

Are the dynamic `System.import` calls (as called out above on lines 45 and 57) absolutely necessary? Having to shut off a highly recommended piece of webpack feels hacky. I know this is an issue not related to angular, but given that angular and webpack are so closely tied to each other I'd expect them to play nice.

Hi!
These errors are produced by autogenerated code appended by HMR-plugin. I've already made pull request to fix the problem, but it hasn't been approved yet. https://github.com/AngularClass/angular2-hmr-loader/pull/3

As a temporary fix you can apply the same changes to the file in your `node_modules`.

In Webpack 2, resolvers from `root`, `modulesDirectories`, and `fallback` settings merge into a single property – `modules`. You should add these to the `modules`.

I'v noticed the root option missing too, but could not figure out via history when that happened. There seem to be no `fallback` option in use in any starter's config file, so only root is needed. When `modules` behave like [modulesDirectories](https://webpack.github.io/docs/configuration.html#resolve-modulesdirectories) we still need absolute path, or it will look up ancestors and if it finds `src` read from there. Or do you think the odds are not higher than this to happen with `node_modules`?

I have a question:

Is it possible to use dashes instead of %20 blank space seperator in urls?

I want to have friendly Urls, with the title of a project and its ID

`[routerLink]="['/project', project.Description]`

Url looks like this at the moment: project/enterprise%20apps%20team%20developer
and I want it to look like this: project/enterprise-apps-team-developer-208
where 208 is the ID

You need to handle `project.Description` assuming that's where "enterprise-apps-team-developer" is coming from. Type it with dashes. Its only doing %20 because you used spaces in the description somewhere.

### Considering becoming an Angular CLI template or using @ngtools/webpack

With the Angular CLI becoming so powerful and central to workflow, it's a good time to consider if this starter makes sense to work as an Angular CLI template. See "[App Creation Using Template](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/wiki/Stories#app-creation-using-template)" in the CLI wiki. Becoming a template would look something like this for a user to get started:

`ng new my-ng2-app --template=angular2-webpack-starter`

Or adopting [`@ngtools/webpack`](https://www.npmjs.com/~ngtools) to not miss out on any of the innovations happening on the CLI like "code splitting" (see below) and other optimizations. 

See the benefits and ability to use `@ngtools/webpack` standalone from the Angular CLI as presented in [Stephen Fluin's Angular CLI talk](https://youtu.be/uBRK6cTr4Vk?t=6m45s) at Angular Connect 2016:
- Compiles SCSS/LESS
- TypeScript transpilation
- Bundles JavaScript, CSS
- Asset optimization
- Virtual filesystem for assets
  - For serving local assets and compile versions.
- Live-reload via websockets
- Code splitting
  - Recognizing the use of loadChildren in the router, and bundling those modules separately so that any dependencies of those modules are not going to be loaded as part of your main bundle. These separate bundles will be pulled out of the critical path of your application, making your total application bundle much smaller and loading it much more performant.

The next change to the repo would diverge from the current folder structure and the current style guide with the focus on production apps. The change would also include AoT,  DLL only for dev and SCSS (since it's the most popular one). Anything the CLI has will be included plus more depending on the opinions and style guide of @AngularClass. The only problem right now is finding the weekend to work on it or start training maintainers for future updates. The CLI and starter repos have different goals which is why this repo will always exist.

- **Question:**

Since the release of RC5 and `NgModule`, you are using `System.import` to load modules asynchronously. I was just wondering why. Since we are using webpack, is it redundant to have SystemJS ?
- **Please tell us about your environment:**

Angular version: 2.0.0-rc.5
I also would like to know this. We were using es6-promise-loader before right?
Maybe because is the recommended way by the Angular 2 staff, however since this repo was already working with `es6-promise-loader` i do wonder why.

Do not confuse `System.import` with SystemJS. `System.import` is to have dynamic `imports` and SystemJS is the Polyfill to allow to do this today. `System.import` is using ES6 promises, so not much different then what `es6-promise-loader` does. See [here](http://exploringjs.com/es6/ch_modules.html)

That does make sense, instead of depending on that loader is best to rely on SystemJS to polyfill the `System.import` that JS is supposed to have in the future, basically getting ready for the future hoping some day we could drop the SystemJS library used to polyfill the import.

@katallaxie Is that right?

No, I think there are 2 things with the same name : SystemJS.

On one hand, there is the SystemJS that we all know - the module loader - and on the other hand there is the module loader API for ES6, the one we are using here.

I heard about it but I didn't know that they have the same name.

_ I'm not sure but that is what I understand._

@mildful SystemJS wants to harvest the same mechanism as `System.import` will do. Dynamically load modules. They provide an API based on `Promise`, which is polyfilled, that emulates this of `System.import`. What SystemJS and Webpack do in addition, is to produce these modules. So, the goal of SystemJS is, to have `System.import` work today, in all browsers, and to have the modules produced.
So it is in deed working as a polyfill in this context.

We are using the keywords `System.import` but it's not related to SystemJS since it's inlined as promises. Webpack 2 gives us this new promise base syntax which allows us to use that rather than our callback style syntax workaround wrapper (`es6-promise-loader`) `require.ensure`. Also, note that SystemJS uses the `SystemJS` global now to be backwards compatible with the future browser loader spec. See [guybedford/systemjs-webpack-plugin](https://github.com/guybedford/systemjs-webpack-plugin) that will allow SystemJS and Webpack to work together.

Here's how to import custom vendor libraries into the vendor.ts bundle. You can just see a live example of how I'm using it successfully.

- If you want to add custom CSS to that same bundle, then you just add `require('path/to/my.css')` inside of this file just the same as you did the javascript.  Both are shown below:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

Works like a charm!!

That is a good one. Another way on Windows environment is to prefix any command with `start`

Example: `start npm run appserver & start npm run protractor`

This will launch both programs in a new console window, on a different thread that isn't connected to each other. Works for free without any extra packages :-)

The use of a single `&` tells the command to not wait for the previous command to finish before starting the new one, meaning it runs both simultaneously.

However, on linux it will require some changes, one potential is to use previx `xdg-open` before the commands in place of `start`. This would require running 2 different commands since you have 2 environments.

The `concurrently` program might be the easiest way to handle multi environment commands.

- **I'm submitting a ...**
  [X] question about the decisions made in the repository

@katallaxie

While the enthusiasm is great, just slamming home changes without others having the opportunity to vet those changes kind of defeats the point of `community` & `code review`. 30 Commits directly to master, to include those to fix or remove features that shouldn't have landed between 27 Sept & 01 Aug.

It also means that everyone that uses the webpack-starter as a base project has to pick up those changes and merge them into what is usually a modified project, it gets tedious quickly.

I'm suggesting you start delivering changes as `complete, tested & vetted sets of work` through the standard `pull request` workflow that everyone else uses thus making the update process less labor intensive and less prone to blowing up peoples forks (which happened to me last week). 

`Landing your own code` is generally `frowned upon` and for good reason. A second ( or multiple ) sets of eyes is never, ever a bad thing.

![screen shot 2016-09-02 at 8 23 50 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8420490/18205263/a9dad192-70e6-11e6-8701-664f551ede99.png)

//cc @gdi2290

This was in my PR https://github.com/AngularClass/angular2-webpack-starter/pull/944. Which I had @gdi2290 ask to comment on. The changes were perhaps a bit more complicated; but it was to the final removal of some APIs.
Which you then merged yourself

Yep, if so this caused you trouble, then I apologize for that. I thought it would be best, as Angular is not final, to keep up with development to be stable or 'more' production ready as soon as possible. Perhaps it would be best to work with the gitflow and create a develop branch.

I'm not suggesting adding full `gitflow` as it usually feels like overkill, even for most of my professional stuff.

What I am suggesting is code not be committed directly to `origin/master` and rather using a standard `pull request workflow` where changes are PR'd, reviewed & then merged by a party != the authoring dev.

I fully agree on the review, and on the need to have all tests passed (fixed this with https://github.com/AngularClass/angular2-webpack-starter/commit/63b241953f9bf9d5c70fbb787b5738db7191989e), but I do not fully agree on the merge itself.

Hi Patrick,
i appreciate Angularclass very much.
I have several days ago paid the bundle subscription to angularclass which is supposed to start end of august 2016, but did not get an answer or access to the courses?

Patrick,
can you please clarify

Hey @HansS sorry we weren't more transparent and thanks for purchasing the Master Bundle. We have the courses on a new schedule that is not reflected on the website and the order might change up a bit. This is mostly due to fit Angular 2's release which is very soon and due to the recent changes in `2.0.0-rc.5`. We thought it would be better if we recreate the courses using the new approach after Angular 2 is released. The delay of the reactive course is mostly my fault going back and forth with @Hendrixer on if we should teach our new reactive architecture that we have, or to use the [angular2-observe-decorators](https://github.com/AngularClass/angular2-observe-decorators), or to focus only on reactivity and state management (our original plan). We were also thinking about if we should teach more RxJS or move that into the Modern JavaScript course or provide that as a mini-course. We decided to stick with our original plan because the observe-decorators is teaching a new way to manage your app with my own proposed spec that might change if it's merged with the Angular codebase. Our new reactive architecture has all of the features that everyone is talking about (rxjs, redux, sagas, effects) plus a ton of features that no-one is talking about (past/present/future states, interop, priority rendering, isolated loops, hot module replacement, webworkers, universal) and would need a few more iterations to unify the whole story. A lot of sugar is needed before we release it to make the API more intuitive and will most likely be a free course.

Hey guys,
We are currently trying to create native apps from our angular2 webpack starter created projects.

Is there an easy way to create an app from the webpack starter for iOS/Android, that behaves like the browser web app? (same but with fullscreen mode). 

It doesn't have to be nativescript, if there exists another possibility like Ionic 2.. Maybe somebody has good experiences with it.

Ionic 2 is build upon PhoneGap; so it is a glorified WebView on the various supported platforms. NativeScript 2.x has moved to the same approach as ReactNative; which is to use JavaScript to wrap around the native frameworks. So, you have decide if you want to go with the Ionic approach, or the other. I would highly recommend second. There is a new an interesting project https://github.com/angular/react-native-renderer which essentially uses Angular 2 on the JavaScript UI Control Thread.

@katallaxie thank you!

The problem with the react-native-renderer approach ist, that we lose the advantage of webpack. I really like this repository as a boilerplate for angular2 apps.

With some additions, like icons, and some other things in the index.html, you can use everything that is in `dist` and deploy it via Cordova to any supported device. Perhaps you could draw something of https://github.com/katallaxie/generator-i-want-nice-ng-cordova which I created a while ago.
@katallaxie thx for your second proposal. but isn't there anything to consider when using webpack?
It just a glorified Browser 😄 .
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3246782/18180268/5f172382-7086-11e6-88a9-b0c837868160.png)
Cordova just wraps a WebView and opens the files in the filesystem with it.
ah okay, so webpack renders the stuff to the /dist folder and cordova takes the shit and wraps the awesome WebView! Sheeesh
Yep! 🎱 Again, you could take some generator and mix it with the starter.

I have the same exact bug with that package, but it does not seem to be related to angular2-webpack-starter, since it also happens by just using webpack. I guess it's ng2-datetime that did not do something correctly (or at least is not compliant with RC5).
It's not related to webpack, it's because NKDateTime dépends on angular RC4.

Okay, to overcome the issue, I needed to set tsconfig.json compilerOptions.lib from "es6" to "es7" as follows:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

I'm not sure if this causes other problems, though. "includes" is implemented for 'string' (not Array<string>) in ES6, and for arrays only in ES7.

any updates on this?

btw I did a different approach to do what `includes()` do

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

@KhaledElAnsari 

I don't think any updates are needed for this, since if you want to use ES7 features on your code, you have to set the "lib" version in tsconfig.json (and tsconfig.webpack.json) to "es7".

So I can't see any issues on Angular2 webpack starter or Angular2 itself regarding this. Just set the library version you want, and you are good to go.

This issue should be closed, or maybe the default library setting should be changed to ES7.
What worked for me was just declare array with also its datatype like as:  let array = []; instead of just let array; where is its datatype undefined.

@jussikinnula Thanks man, your repo helped my diagnose what was wrong with mine.

Turns out that `angular2-template-loader` cannot understand line comments inside of the routes object. During testing, I had a lot of variations commented out on one of my sub module routes, like this:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

But that gives many errors. Just by removing the line comments, it fixed it:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

That was tricky to diagnose.

The second part of my fix was that on my typescript loader, I was using `'angular2-router-loader'`, but it never worked as expected. Then, I saw in your repo that you have `'angular2-router-loader?loader=system'`, so I tried it, and that did the trick!

So lessons: 
- add query `?loader=system` to `angular2-router-loader`
- don't use any line comments within routes object for sub modules loaded by `angular2-router-loader`

Semanic UI is a jQuery library, so you'll need to add this loader to your `webpack.common.js` file:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

This exposes any jquery anytime it is require()'d to the global context.
Then, require jquery inside your `some.component.ts` file :

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

You'll need to redeclare the jQuery constant inside each component that will use jQuery. Its possible to refactor the jQuery require so you don't have to manually redeclare it in each component, but I have had unreliable results with that approach. Importing manually in each component is reliable so far.

You also need to add

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

as a dependencies in `package.json`

Now you should be able to use your Semanic UI jquery code in your components.

It seems that the file **head-config.common.js** is not watched by **tsc** or **webpack**, so if you make a change in this file, you have to do a `npm start`.

Is there a better way to fix this ?

That's because its inside of webpack options, and webpack options are not watched for changes. Any change to webpack config will require relaunching the `webpack-dev-server` or a recompile using `webpack` CLI. 

I don't know if what you're asking is possible with webpack since it isn't designed to watch it's own config for changes.

The `head-config.common.js` is just a programmatic way to construct `index.html`. You can add them directly in the index.html, or through head-config.common.js and it outputs the exact same thing.

However, I think it is not correct to load them in the head either way. Personally I do not load vendor libaries that way because you have webpack at your command. Rather that making all those network requests, just bundle the library into your `vendor.ts` webpack bundle.

@gdi2290 @Spittal @qdouble @unsafecode working on `@ngtools/webpack`. I have pushed some things, more work to do. But help is always welcome.

@katallaxie some game breakers for me are
1) ViewEncapsulation.None or Emulated break the build or cause styles not to import properly: 
https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/2584

2) Nested types are often not properly resolved
It's related to this TS bug https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/issues/9944, however if I use my starter where I compile and build as two different processes, the bug doesn't occur

3) It strips custom decorators: https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/2799

Once those 3 issues are solved, I'll switch over to it, but for now it seems like a bigger hassle to use it rather than just using the scripts to process it as separate tasks.
@qdouble yep, there are some remaining issues. However, can we test `v6` and move it, or stop it?!
The view encapsulation thing can be fixed by just using the style-loader and an import statement.
@paralin You're right, this workaround works - but it's actually counterintuitive. I really hope all this bugs are fixed soon, otherwise AoT will remain a mirage for non-trivial projects...
@unsafecode @paralin AoT uses static code analysis, so you must use `import` statements rather then `require` which are dynamic. There are some other issues with AoT.

@paralin not fully, well that may be a workaround for ViewEncasuplation.None, it's not a good workaround for Emulated. 

Seems it may be a while before it's worth using ngtools when you can just avoid a bunch of the bugs by just compiling with ngc as a separate process.

Agree with @qdouble here. As it stands right now, I'm loving AoT but I have implemented it professionally in a similar fashion to Anthony, separate tasks executed explicitly. @ngtools/webpack has some outstanding issues that are blocking it's usefulness.

Small implementation details aside, the only really viable way to get AoT working in a meaningful way would be the route @qdouble took. Kind of wish I would have seen his starter prior to doing all that work myself :/ as we ended up in a similar place.

_**If the intent is to get AoT into this starter sooner rather than later,  qdouble/angular-webpack2-starter would be the path forward.**_ 

That said, there are some pretty significant challenges with AoT once you grow your application to anything of production size. `AoT is a commitment to building in a specific way`, most of which won't be apparent with the small starter application. For instance, anyone using Sass in the normal fashion of using require statements in components for styles are going to have a lot of work to do. 

If we are going to land AoT now, everyone should be ready for the onslaught of questions and issues when people try to pull in AoT enabled #master and their builds explode ( been there ... lol ). 

Also worth noting, if we are going to release AoT support we definitely need to test the AoT builds for PRs or we are going to be breaking master every other day ( been there too ).

@d3viant0ne say what, I'm not sure what the earlier version of that comment was, but I've long since had to move to @qdouble's starter, so I doubt I was threatening **_I_** was gonna go anywhere.

I've been advocating this starter over others for a long time and was closely following the V6 branch(which was blocked by ngtools issues at the time) which I found superior to what I'm using(as it's based on what I'm using). As soon as all the issues I knew about were resolved, I [tried](https://github.com/AngularClass/angular2-webpack-starter/issues/885#issuecomment-267594608) getting a status update on it, didn't get any answer and instead this issue, which was the only [issue V6 was discussed at](https://github.com/AngularClass/angular2-webpack-starter/issues/885#issuecomment-255840442), as far as I know anyway, was closed, which was what prompted my last comment, asking for whether there was, or was going to be another issue created for the V6 branch. I didn't get any reply, which is why I wrote [this](https://github.com/AngularClass/angular2-webpack-starter/issues/1330#issuecomment-270340310).

So how about you cut me a slack, I didn't mean anything offensive in the slightest sense, I'm all up for helping finish that branch but without ever getting an answer about your plans going forward, it's kind of hard.


..and yes, what is currently on master is indeed obsolete, especially at the time I wrote that comment, compared to your V6 branch. At DLLs and the way and the language configs are written in, for example. And I have no idea why should I be sending PRs while you already have a a branch with all the `other stuff` I'm talking about.

@fxck You are 1 of many, you want DLL, thats cool...
Who said it's good for everyone...

Guys calm down, he just was asking where he could find a status update for v6.

People are WAY too quick to get dramatic.
@shlomiassaf cutting development build time in half with no other side effects is good for everyone.

@shlomiassaf geez, DLLs are not even the point. The point was that there is a branch of **_THIS_** repo that already has both AOT and DLLs, is utilising @ngtools/webpack, is written a way more modern way, with all the configs being typesafe and written in typescript and all the while @AngularClass [team members](https://github.com/AngularClass/angular2-webpack-starter/issues/1330#issuecomment-270270806) and collaborators are being completely oblivious to the fact. I honestly couldn't care less, as I had to move to qdouble's starter couple of months ago because I simply couldn't proceed without AOT, but it seems like a wasted chance, time and effort to abandon that branch, unless there are reasons for it, which is what I kept asking for.

I am trying to use GSAP (http://greensock.com/) in angular2-webpack-starter
In the GSAP forum I found a ts typing file.
https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped/blob/master/greensock/greensock.d.ts
But in the angular2-webpack-starter I can really find a typings.json file to add it to. 
Any suggestions? Thanks

As far as I understand this, the Webpack Starter is not using (anymore) Typings, but instead the "@types" that comes with the new version of typescript.

So to solve your problem, first look if there is a "@types" for GSAP.

Else, you can try to paste the content of you ".d.ts" file in the "custom-typings.d.ts" of the Webpack Starter.

Thanks for the quick reply.
Didn't find much about @types and GSAP, don think they support it officially.
I tried moving the content from the .d.ts film to custom-typings. But it created some other issues.
But think I got GSAP to work without typings, so for now I will just do it this way.

But if somebody has experience with GSAP and angular2-webpack-starter please feel free to leave a comment.

_I changed the tsconfig.json - target: "es6" because it's not recognizing "Set" and others es6_

I encounter the same issue when including a 3rd party library which is build in es6.
I can reproduce this as well.
Same here. Setting target to es5 works as workaround.

Installing the npm package: typescript@rc and setting the target: "es5" in tsconfig.json solved it for me..

Problem was I couldn't use target: "es5" before because my project is using async / await.. But with the new 2.1 version of Typescript it is supported
I've got the same issue when trying to change target to ES6.

Confirming this as well. I am using ES6 target for async/await support, and that causes UglifyJS to fail. Setting ES5 target with Typescript 2.0.10 breaks the async/await... So I'm between a rock and a hard place here.

I'm trying to get things working with newer Typescript.

"I'm trying to get things working with newer Typescript."

Build works with Typescript 2.1.5 & ES5 Target BUT async/await doesn't work!

"__generator is not defined"

__generator is part of async/await code generated by Typescript when the target is ES5 or ES3.

Disabling UglifyJS completely allows production builds with ES6 target, so that's what I'm currently doing as a workaround. Might still test ES5 target with manually copy & pasted __generator and __awaiter from https://blog.mariusschulz.com/2016/12/09/typescript-2-1-async-await-for-es3-es5
I found a solution by using babel. ES6 Typescript -> JavaScript es6 -> babel -> es5.

Workaround with TS 2.1 & ES5 target without babel is to copy & paste __generator & __awaiter vars to index.html or other place to be included on global scope. I tested it and it's indeed working.

Get the code from the following link:

https://blog.mariusschulz.com/2016/12/09/typescript-2-1-async-await-for-es3-es5

Feels a bit dirty but works. Honestly, I think that using babel with TS would be even bigger sin.

Good luck with your project :sparkles: You rock! :palm_tree: --- [GitHub Release](https://github.com/karma-runner/karma/releases/tag/v1.2.0)

Bug Fixes

  • context: Updated postMessage listener to stop validating non-Karma messages (306e565)
  • docs: fix stopper.stop wrong variable name. closes #2244 (0745a00), closes #2244
  • file-list: ensure patterns are comparable (4d1bf3e), closes #2194
  • middleware: fix WARN log when passing undefined error handler to promise.then (20b87de), closes #2227
  • call .resume to prevent browser output streams filling up (107cd02)
  • Merge config child nodes on config.set() (65b688a)
  • web-server: Allow karma to run in project which path contains HTML URL encoded characters. Karma fails on Jenkins when it checks out branches containing '/' as it converts it to '%2F'. Fixes errors seen on #1751, #61. (da1930f), closes #1751 #61

`@NgModule` was the only thing preventing Angular from being released. The only thing that will delay Angular 2 from being released is if they decide to rename `@NgModule` to something else like `@Container`. @BeanoKing I also have a prod app on this. I'd say stay with what you have for now. The NgModule stuff will be resolved / tweaked by the next RC. Same with Webpack 2.

@MacBaird The problem is the hot loading stuff / Angular Universal (server side rendering) is not really compatible with the new NgModule requirements (list all the dependencies at module creation time). We're trying to work it out with the Universal team and Angular upstream.

I have a feeling @gdi2290 is waiting for rc.6 because he knows about some breaking changes we don't... or he could just be busy with actual work. 😊 Either way I'm hesitant to update my apps until I see how's rc.5 handled in this repo.
And he'd be right to wait for RC6.

@alvipeo Fwiw, I'm using Webpack2, Typescript2, Angular2 RC5 in a 150+ components, 10 ngModules site that we'll release to business customers very soon. 

It works very well and I'm (after initial depressive thoughts) very happy about the ngModules stuff. It makes it so much nicer and easier to structure larger projects into different parts.

I haven't implemented AoT compilation yet though.

As for RC6 - this will be a bugfix release, and a "remove-deprecated-apis"-relelase.

If your app works with RC5 without warning messages deprecated use of APIs, it should be working out of the box with RC6... I'm pretty sure about this.

Currently, when a background url(...) statement is used in CSS, webpack tries to incorrectly process the file reference as javascript. This causes a build error.
- **What is the new behavior (if this is a feature change)?**

Adding a file-loader to handle jpg/png/gif files fixes this.
- **Other information**:

Added use of file-loader for jpg/png/gif files. This adds support for using background url() statements in CSS files, as per https://github.com/AngularClass/angular2-webpack-starter/issues/759

Why u dont use [https://github.com/Quramy/angular2-load-children-loader](https://github.com/Quramy/angular2-load-children-loader) ? (for webpack 2)

with es6-promise its look like,

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

Me? this repo? anyway it's to be more in sync with the future of JS, `System.import` though not yet available is part of the ES6 specification, thus when it is ready to be used the change should be minimal.

At the end it is roughly the same result, only that the `System.import` way will be ready for when that feature in the ES6 spec is available everywhere.

https://github.com/doxiaodong/darlin-angular2/blob/master/src/app/app.routes.ts#L10
work fine with me

just modify this code to imports section, replace this:
RouterModule.forRoot(ROUTES, {useHash: false, preloadingStrategy: PreloadAllModules}),
with this:
RouterModule.forRoot(ROUTES, {useHash: false, preloadingStrategy: NoPreloading}),

more information at here:
https://angular.io/docs/ts/latest/guide/router.html#!#custom-preloading-strategy

Currently the first non-comment line in custom.d.ts is as follows 

`declare module "*";` 

but that seems to give a syntax error on the semicolon with the message '{ expected', as the compiler expects a curly brace.  Changing it to the following seems to fix it

`declare module "*" {}`

Is that a valid fix?
IntelliJ has been complaining about this for me as well. I'd love to know what's the proper way of resolving this..

I have a related problem with `declare module "*";`, when included my WebStorm fails to provide TypeScript support for all other modules, and trying to jump any module results in jumping to this line. Is this line necessary?
https://youtrack.jetbrains.com/issue/WEB-22697

- **What kind of change does this PR introduce?** (Bug fix, feature, docs update, ...)
  Enhancement
- **What is the current behavior?** (You can also link to an open issue here)

Production configuration lets you configure host and port, but dev configuration does not. It defaults to localhost and port 3000.

Fixes issue:
https://github.com/AngularClass/angular2-webpack-starter/issues/821
And partially:
https://github.com/AngularClass/angular2-webpack-starter/issues/186
- **What is the new behavior (if this is a feature change)?**

Now to run dev server on a VM you can just run
PORT=8081 HOST="0.0.0.0" npm run server:dev:hmr
or if you're using "forever"
PORT=8081 HOST="0.0.0.0" forever start -v --minUptime 1000 --spinSleepTime 1000 -c "npm run server:dev:hmr" ./
- **Other information**:

I'm using this to setup an automated Vagrant setup, and this way I can make all the changes in scripts instead of by hand. This also brings the dev config closer to the prod config.

Was having the same issue, thanks for the solution... Nonetheless, could we update tsconfig.json accordingly since probably everyone is having/going to have the same problem? Or is there any particular reason why this is not updated yet?
I resolved my issue my adding es6 target in tsconfig, removing @types/core-js, and keeping core-js dependency.

I think this is resolved with ee0c85e1483b7f77ad728ab8c177d4370eb07250. But, you should not change the target from `es5` to `es6` as because of best browser support. See [Compiler Options](https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/compiler-options.html).

It is indeed resolved by removing `core-js` from the `types` array in `tsconfig.json`.
No need to resort to changing the compiler target to `es6`.

- **What is the current behavior?**
  Git by defult treat directory 'tmp' in main directory as 'ignore'. But when I put to tmp copy of node_modules dir, then project was unable to compile in production mode. Because typescript thrown 'Duplication' problems (becouse it 'scan' tmp/node_modules dir...)
- **If the current behavior is a bug, please provide the steps to reproduce and if possible a But when I put to 'tmp/' copy of node_modules dir, then project was unable to compile in production mode. Because typescript thrown 'Duplication' problems (becouse it 'scan' tmp/node_modules dir...)
- **What is the expected behavior?**
  Ignore 'tmp' directory by typescript. We can do it by edit exclude section in tsconfig.json
  It should look like this:
  ...
  "exclude": [
    "node_modules",
    "tmp"

Hey guys,
- I have a project on which I've used this excellent starter as a base. Each time there are updates, I've updated my application - everything's been smooth.

But after updating to Typescript2.0 and @typings  I get some weird errors when I try to serve my app in development mode. During Webpack build, I get the following errors, after which my build halts completely without further messages.

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

When I look in the node_modules/typedoc folder, there isn't even a src folder!
Anyone have an idea of what the ***\* could be referencing typedoc source?

I've tried uninstall typedoc to no avail

Cheers
I believe `typedoc` doesn't support TypeScript 2 yet.
Hi @abdulhaq-e  - that's true - but I don't even run typedoc.. and I'm getting same errors even if I uninstall typedoc..  this is so weird

Ok I found the error - and maybe it can be of interest to people upgrading this project by hand.

I turns out - that yes, typedoc does not support typescript2.0 yet.
So far so good - I removed typedoc, BUT  node_modules/.bin/typedoc was not removed in that process.

So: if you upgrade to TS2.0, make sure you remove tsdoc completely - ALSO in the node_modules/.bin folder.

Thanks guys, closing the case.

when a use  interface canActivate to secure a route, console give me this message 

>  zone.js:260 Uncaught Invalid provider - only instances of Provider and Type are allowed, got: undefined
>

you can't use an interface because they get removed after build. you need to use a service that has the method and you need to provide the service on the root or in this case the APP_RESOLVER_PROVIDERS

Hi, I'm trying to use this starter as a wordpress theme, I got it to work but I have a problem with loading assets files and relative paths, since it is designed to be loaded from root directory, and I know supporting wordpress is out of the scope of this repo but I was wondering if I can add custom paths to webpack so it can recognize them and load them from the theme directory instead of root directory.

for example let's say that the url is `http://example.com` but the app is located in `http://example.com/wp-content/themes/angular2-webpack-starter`, is it possible to get it to work?

you would just set the baseUrl correct
`<base href="/wp-content/themes/angular2-webpack-starter">`
@marsanla not sure if this will help, but in your webpack.prod.js, in the output block, set And for example, in your img tags like , use instead of do
In the custom_typings.d.ts file, if we add the line `import * as _ from 'lodash';` we end up getting an error at compile time saying `Cannot find name 'ENV'`. Anyone else run across this?

that was meant as an example of where you would use it within app not custom-typings.d.ts the line you're looking for is

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

but you're better off just installing it from typings
`typings install dt~lodash --save --global`
then you should be able to use it within your `app/` so long as you also install it via `npm install lodash`

Problem:

I am using this project as baseline to setup a new project. After starting the node using webpack dev server , CPU usage in my windows machine is going to 100%. I have 16GB RAM. Has anyone faced this issue and know the solution?

I've noticed the same thing. I didn't dig deeper, but the CPU usage did drop immediately as soon as a shut down node and Chrome.

Were you using HMR by any chance? I was...

@Martaver - Nope I am not using the HMR. I am using npm run server:dev which is actually "webpack-dev-server --config config/webpack.dev.js --inline --progress --profile --colors --watch --display-error-details --display-cached --content-base src/" . I am sure this is because of web pack dev server running on node but not sure what is the solution for this.
I found out that it was happening because of webpack dev server watchOptions. If you increase the poll time then CPU usage goes down.

I know it is closed already but I will put my discover that, believe it or not (I still can hardly believe it), if you are on a Windows machine the problem is how you get to the path where your app is... I will explain myself:
If you have in D:\Projects\project_whatever your project and you go `cd d:`, then `cd project`... and so on, that will break webpack, but if you go `cd D:` then `cd Project` it will work!
Webpack will break if you don't follow exactly the same case. As simple and stupid as that...
Hopefully this helps somebody with the same problem in the future.
I believe this is related: Microsoft/vscode#9448

You need to teach webpack how to handle this file type (`*.jpg`). Otherwise it's assumed to be a js module.

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

This uses the [webpack/file-loader](https://github.com/webpack/file-loader) that copies the referenced assets (the jpg) to the output folder and leaves behind an URL for the browser to load.

I invite you to browse the (long) list of loaders: http://webpack.github.io/docs/list-of-loaders.html
It's quite interesting to see what other loaders are available, like the `url-loader` that turns the file contents into `data:` urls.

Was looking into your issue, @xeor, and found that my fix, doesn't actually seem to fix anything. 

Near as I can tell, the issue went away when I switched to using root-relative background-image url(...)... with some mixup I attributed this to using the file-loader, but so far, it seems that even if I delete these loaders it works, as long as I'm using root-relative URLs.

This relates to css-loader's [root relative URLs feature](https://github.com/webpack/css-loader#root-relative-urls). 

The original issue, then, is still unsolved.

A quick workaround, I guess, is to just use root-relative urls, such as: `background-image url(/assets/img/myimg.jpeg)`

@gdi2290 Hi Patrick, I did not change anything in the config, however, I managed to get it working again.
After disabling my components one by one, I found out that this particular import causes the error:
`import {Subscription} from "rxjs/Rx";`
Commenting this import resolves the issue. I wanted to do something like `this.subscription.unsubscribe()` on a component's `ngOnDestroy` where `this.subscription`'s type is set to 'Subscription' imported from `rxjs/Rx`.

Strange that this causes Webpack to compile into ES6 though. Worth looking into?

Update: I'm using WebStorm 2016.1 and `rxjs/Rx` is the only file WebStorm recommends me to import `Subscription` from.
I'm reopening this issue so people are aware of this behaviour and can provide some explanation / feedback

I'm submitting a 
feature request

I am using node.js 5.12.0 and NPM 3.8.6

When i open my site in System browser its taking 3 to 4 seconds to load/open.
Same site if i open in mobile phones its taking 8 to 10 seconds.
I want to reduce the time taken by load the app second time. 2nd time files are serving from cache. 
If all files serving from cache also taking same time to load page.

`RouterModule.forRoot(ROUTES, { useHash: true }),`

and instead use this:

`RouterModule.forRoot(ROUTES),`

- **I'm submitting a ...**
  [x] feature request
- **Do you want to request a _feature_ or report a _bug_?**
  A feature
- **What is the current behavior?**
  There's no current support for [Static Template Compilation](http://teropa.info/blog/2016/05/19/things-that-excite-me-about-angular-2.html#static-template-compilation) nor [Web Workers](http://teropa.info/blog/2016/05/19/things-that-excite-me-about-angular-2.html#web-worker-support) nor [Service Workers](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Service_Worker_API)
- **What is the expected behavior?**
  Have support for those 3 technologies in the app.
- **What is the motivation / use case for changing the behavior?**
  - Static template compilation: Speed up the render process and performance as well as lowering the size of the bundles.
  - Web Workers: Offloading resource intensive operations to a new thread thus making better use of multicore cpus (today even mobile have multicore).
  - Service workers: Mainly to support offline applications using libs like [sw-precache](https://github.com/GoogleChrome/sw-precache) or [sw-toolbox](https://github.com/GoogleChrome/sw-toolbox), but also to support background sync and push notifications.  
- **Other information**
  Here are some links about those subjects:
  - [Static Template Compilation](http://teropa.info/blog/2016/05/19/things-that-excite-me-about-angular-2.html#static-template-compilation)
  - [Web Workers](http://teropa.info/blog/2016/05/19/things-that-excite-me-about-angular-2.html#web-worker-support)
  - [Service Workers](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Service_Worker_API)
  - [The difference between Service Workers, Web Workers and WebSockets](https://aarontgrogg.com/blog/2015/07/20/the-difference-between-service-workers-web-workers-and-websockets)

Aditionally i'm working on the sw and sw-precache feature myself so i can provide some help in that field.

I've been digging in how to integrate webworkers with offline mode in webpack and so far i have seen 2 plugins that takes care of that:
- [Offline plugin](https://github.com/NekR/offline-plugin)
- [sw-precache-webpack-plugin](https://github.com/goldhand/sw-precache-webpack-plugin)

So far it seems the Offline plugin is better since it states that it fallbacks to AppCache if service worker isn't supported in the browser, this plugin will only cache the webpack generated files, basically the source code, meanwhile the sw-precache-webpack-plugin has a ton more configuration options about caching other requests like images, videos and api data, basically any regex pattern for request the user wants to define, further testing and analysis required.

After analysing the current support i take for granted that the best tool is Offline plugin since it allows to use a fallback to AppCache, the browsers related are Safari (partial support) and Edge (currently only available from development builds).

Resource (support table):  [isserviceworkerready](https://jakearchibald.github.io/isserviceworkerready)

After a bit more testing i still think the `Offline plugin` is the way to go, it works excelent to generate both the service worker for offline support and the cache manifest as fallback, as well as caching the app.

Meanwhile the `sw-precache-webpack-plugin` doesn't offer any fallback without support for service worker, it caches fine when in supported browsers, however docs are a bit outdated comparing to the code, and there's some weird behaviour where in production the service worker just generates 1 cache for each file instead of putting all files in the same cache, which i think is due to the `UglifyJsPlugin` plugin, idk if it's expected behaviour or a bug.

Lastly the `sw-precache-webpack-plugin` will not work with dev server as the generated service worker doesn't get served by the `webpack-dev-server`.
ya, eventually these will all be added

Good luck with your project :sparkles: You rock! :palm_tree: --- [GitHub Release](https://github.com/karma-runner/karma/releases/tag/v1.0.0)

Bug Fixes

  • ci: Repaired AppVeyor for Node.js@0.12 (cbfd98c)
  • client: does not throws an error for non DOM object that has tagName property (ba55afb), closes #2139
  • files: Ignore included:false pattern (db42a7f), closes #1530
  • helper: Patched replaceWinPath from choking on null values (caa4d21)
  • karma: Escape quotes for file names. This fixes issue #1876. (9dff3f3), closes #1876 #1876
  • launcher: Allow dynamic browser launches (2b7d703)
  • launcher: send sigkill on timeout when force killing (c615c1f)
  • proxy: Port mixup and infinite loop (05616a2), closes #1987
  • reporter: Better handling of non string error (82f1c12)
  • reporter: Disable source maps for URLs without line number (2080221), closes #1274
  • Change timing on test (0cb6204)
  • Setting default value for config in runner and stopper (414db89)
  • reporters: Fix results not being reported (6303566)
  • reporters: Throwing error without loosing stack trace (8a515ae)
  • runner: Merge config.client.args with client.args provided by run (91de383), closes #1746
  • updater: Fix time unit on screen display from 'ms' to 'seconds'. (f39dd04)
  • web-server: Restart disconnected browser in non-singleRun mode. (f6587dc)
  • web-server: Update config on every request (8ef475f), closes #1972

Code Refactoring

  • context: Future-proofed context.html and debug.html for modularity (43f6a1a)

Features

  • browser: Emit a browser error when a disconnect occurs. (e36ba6c)
  • config: Add configuration for adding javascript version. (0239c75), closes #1719
  • config: Allow custom context and debug files, with feature test and some specs. (225c0e5)
  • file-list: Upgrade bluebird to v.3 (f5c252f)
  • logging: Add colors and log-level options to run-command (9d4e234)
  • logging: Add logging-setup function (d14bd62)
  • logging: Send color option to server (287d0db)
  • preprocessors: if a file matches multiple preprocessor patterns, intelligently merge the list of preprocessors, deduping and trying to preserve the order (59642a6)
  • reporter: improve source map handling and reporting. (cf0be47)
  • reporters: Look for color-reporter (fd9262d)
  • server: add 'listening' event with port number (82cd0df)
  • Add stopper to the public API (3d4fa00)
  • Add possibility to stop a karma server (66ae80b)
  • add support for node 6 (0b8dc2c)
  • adding support for before middleware (51b4206)
  • stopper: Enable programically detached server (f10fd81)
  • Fail on launcher-, reporter-, plugin-, or preprocessor-load errors. (fca930e), closes #855
  • upgrade dependencies to their latest versions (08242a0)

BREAKING CHANGES

  • context: Our context.html and debug.html structures have changed to lean on context.js and debug.js. This is in preparation for deeper context.js changes in #1984.

As a result, all customContextFile and customDebugFile options much update their format
to match this new format.

Hi,

If we need to include [jQuery](https://jquery.com/), instructions given in the [wiki](https://github.com/AngularClass/angular2-webpack-starter/wiki/How-to-include-jQuery) work fine, but **there are some special cases** we need to be aware of.

Let me explain with a simple use case : **adding [Foundation-sites](http://foundation.zurb.com/sites.html) in the project.**

Foundation-sites has a dependency to jQuery, so when installed it will install jQuery in our `node_modules` folder. But in the Foundation-site module, there's also a `vendor`folder that provide JQuery too (**and not necessary the same** than the one listed in the `package.json`'s dependencies of the Foundation-site module).

So, if we follow only your instructions, for this use case, **these two versions of jQuery will be imported** in the generated `vendor.js` bundle.

We can handle these kind of thing with a **[null-loader](https://github.com/webpack/null-loader) webpack loader** for things we want to be sure they'll not be imported.

Something like that  :

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

Obviously, only the `webpack.ProvidePlugin` method is concerned. Maybe add some other methods (like with [script-loader](https://github.com/webpack/script-loader) for instance) could also be useful, don't you think?

Don't you think these informations could be useful for others? If so, maybe you should add them in the [Wiki](https://github.com/AngularClass/angular2-webpack-starter/wiki)?
ya, can you update the wiki to mention this. Thanks!

I realized that I don't identified the reason well. 

If there is no jquery module as "root module" (in the root of the main node_modules folder), and you install foundation-sites, this jquery module will be installed as "root module". And your solution works well. 

But if another module depends on jQuery, and if it is not the same than the previous one,  when installed, the "previous one" will be copied in the foundation-sites's node_modules  directory, and the "new one" as "root module".

In this case, we need the solution I provided. 

Let me do other tests, clean everything and I'll update the wiki ;)

- **What is the current behavior?**
  The package.json file lists project dependencies. 
  I noticed that a lot of the "project" packages, for example @angular/\*  are  listed in the dependencies section.

I assume that when a project is built, all dependencies are put into the bundle files.
Therefore I would assume that all the files in the "dependencies" section really should be in the "devDependencies" section.

Let's for example say that you want to add a node backend (which is reasonable to think). 
You would install packages for the backend, and when you deploy the application you would copy your backend source to the destination server, and then run "npm install --production"

This would effectively install all the @angular/\* packages in the production environment. A behaviour you don't want. Npm install --production installs all packages listed in the "dependencies" section.

So my question is:
Is there something I've completely missed - or should we not move all packages into the "devDependencies" section?

If not, how would you distinct packages to be installed in a production environment, when adding a node backend?

Cheers, guys, really appreciate this project, it has helped me tremendously in setting up the exact environment I need for my projects.

Hi, i think is more about concept than about actual use, off course you can put `@angular` dependencies in dev since most users just install in production by uploading the bundled files and installing the server deps.

The concept i talk is that devDeps are the deps you need during development (mostly webpack, browserify, gulp...) and in normal deps goes the ones your app really use (like @angular/core) so it's about stating in the package that deps are the ones your app requires and devDeps are the ones you use to bundle, compile or deploy your app.

I understand this - however once you try to setup a node backend in the same project, you'll be in trouble.

This is mostly and information to newbies: if you use this excellent repo as a starter for your project, and you also need a backend as part of the project, do yourself a favor and move all dependencies to the "devDependencies" section.

Otherwise you end up installing a lot of modules in your production environment that you won't need.

I will close this issue now ;)

We've updated our project to the angular2-webpack-starter with Angular RC1.
What I've found out by trial and error:

In Firefox
1. NgZone.onStable and NgZone.onUnstable do not occur after the XHR/fetch completes. 
2. I've managed to work around this issue by excluding core-js/es6/promise. So, I suggest that this polyfill breaks angular.

You can see my fix here: https://github.com/borisvasilenko/angular2-webpack-starter/commit/da2ac7966279e120dd00f6b22837960225b30329
thanks, fixed via https://github.com/AngularClass/angular2-webpack-starter/commit/c1d8fd5235a427ceecffd39ada5ccba192905afa

Very strange. Can you write a full reproducible example with all environment?  I'll play with it when I'll have some time.

@zloirock I experienced this bug too with Chrome and Angular rc.3. If I import 'core-js/es6/promise' the page doesn't load all the bindings. There are no errors in console at all. All others files in core-js/es6 folder can be imported without any issue. To reproduce it easly create a very basic project using webpack (you can clone my MEAN stack project) and into vendor.ts try to write "import 'core-js/es6';" or all the files individually, including promise.

Edit: seems solved.

@borisvasilenko learn some angular before start coding.  
If you need data from server best approach to use Http service from '@angular/http'. Because it has required change detection code.

But if you really need to use async code that located outside of angular app, you need to wrap it with [NgZone.run(yourCode)](https://angular.io/docs/ts/latest/api/core/index/NgZone-class.html#!#run-anchor) or finalize it with [ChangeDetectorRef.detectChanges()](https://angular.io/docs/ts/latest/api/core/index/ChangeDetectorRef-class.html#!#detectChanges-anchor)

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/34827334/triggering-angular2-change-detection-manually

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/32768854/using-promises-and-zones-in-angular2

Everything worked perfectly for me with import 'core-js/es6'; and now I have a bug and need manually change polyfills.ts to previous version

Yes, my browser cache was disabled. So, after few experiments I found, what it's google chrome  v51.0 problem. On chrome "canary" all source maps are valid. @gdi2290, thanks for your answer!

@holiber how did you find out that this is a Chrome 51 problem? How did you fix it?

Using `git bisect` today, I found out that the introduction of `momentjs` into our builds broke source maps on Chrome Version 51.0.2704.103 (64-bit).

Webpack config has `devtool: 'cheap-module-source-map'`.

A fix for us was to include either of the following as a Webpack plugin:
- `new webpack.ContextReplacementPlugin(/moment[\/\\]locale$/, /en-us/)`
- `new webpack.IgnorePlugin(/^\.\/locale/, /moment$/)` 

Note that the first solution works but is broken, since there's no `en-us` files in `moment/locale` for v2.13.0 - I just got it via copy-pasta from another project. The second solution should be preferred.

This requires modification to the `index.html` so every `href` and `src` links are properly set.

@valorkin The implementation does use the `gh-pages` package but it wont work out of the box, it need some help getting it to actually work.

The main reason is that in github the base url is always **username**.github.io/**repo-name**. In most cases the application will not have a **repo-name** prefix, it's usually the root of the domain.

So, we have 3 different setups:  
-  Local dev server
-  Deployment in production
-  Deployment in github.

This is why we need an additional config since it a different setup.

We also need to think about the purpose of `angular2-webpack-starter`, it's a set tools aimed to making the developers life easier, not having to manually manage work flows.
Having to run `gh-pages -d dist` manually requires some previous steps, you have to run the build and if you forgot you probably just posted an older version to github, this is a common mistake that happened to me more then once :)
It get's even worse if you forgot to edit your **index.html** to support the github pages base url prefix, again happened to me more then once.
This is actually why I created this flow, then realized it can be integrated into this project.

Another thing is that you can deploy 2 (or more, custom) compilation artefacts to github, minified production build or a development build.

Also, this PR tries to keep it simple so you don't have a lot of configuration options to control the `gh-pages` package, this can be done in a later phase. I prefer a simple PR first so we can understand it.

So using the `gh-pages -d dist` approach you need to do some manual work, which is the same for every release: build and edit `index.html`, this is a prefect scenario for automation.

If you investigate the config file you will see it's basically a simple webpack plugin, I think we should first adopt the PR and then opt for a plugin after we get around most use cases and options to support.

The main issue here is the noise in **index.html**

Having to prefix every resource with `<%= webpackConfig.output.publicPath %>`:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

Add's a lot of noise that I really don't like, and it's "sort of" an API change, this is why I asked @gdi2290 to ask for community help.

BTW, if a user has a public path different then `/` this is something that he needs to do anyway, hardcoding the public path is a recipe for future errors since it can't be refactored automatically.

The solution here is probably defining a static asset array with objects for every  static asset and building them when we compile index.html, something like:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

This allows supporting every attribute out there.
It also doesn't break anything, if someone doesn't want github deployment support he can just hardcode his assets.

All in all, I think it's better to define static assets outside of `index.html` and keep it as clean as possible.

@gdi2290 before I start, some consult.

Since a static asset file has volume I don't think it should be within the configurations themselves.

We can put it in a file, in the config directory... something like
`assets.common.json` or `assets.dev.json` etc... 

In the configs we can opt in for them if the file exists and create the html, this result's in a non breaking API modification.

Another option is to let the user set the json asset file (path) in the config's.

I like the first option better, it's convention over configuration which is less confusion.

- **What kind of change does this PR introduce?** (Bug fix, feature, docs update, ...)
  Bug fix
- **What is the current behavior?** (You can also link to an open issue here)
  When creating a build using `build:dev` the index.html request a javascript resource **webpack-dev-server.js**.
  **webpack-dev-server.js** is used by `webpack-dev-server` which also returns it (the resource).
  Since a build is intended to run in a different web server it will always 404.
- **What is the new behavior (if this is a feature change)?**
  Do not include 'webpack-dev-server.js`script request in builds, only include it when running udner`webpack-dev-server`
- **Other information**:
  The current implementation uses **ENV** to determine if were in development mode, if so include `webpack-dev-server.js`. A build can also be a development mode. To get the real answer a helper function checks for the file used to run the process, if its `webpack-dev-server` then we include the resource.

Adding a css preprocesser is incredibly easy. 

Simply install the corresponding css loader you want, for instance for less you can use https://github.com/webpack/less-loader.

`npm install less-loader -S`

In `./config/webpack.common.js` change the loaders entry from 

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

to 

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

then inside your component

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

The procedure here is the same for sass, or styles. You could also use pre-css/autoprefixer, as I am here: https://github.com/paynoattn/paynoattn-angular2/blob/master/config/webpack.common.js

I'm also working on putting an example of this into the material branch but we have a wiki on it as well: [How to include SCSS in components](https://github.com/AngularClass/angular2-webpack-starter/wiki/How-to-include-SCSS-in-components)

Does anyone know why I am getting duplicates of the webpack runtimes in the bundle? 

It's adding multiple numbers after the ? and the browser is seeing them as new files.
- dev-server.js?
- dev-server.js?52d4
- dev-server.js?53d4*

![webpack-dupes](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/13709948/15556492/faa8f818-2282-11e6-9214-bfd8e551e55b.png)

See the file tree on the left:
![webpack-dupes2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/13709948/15556549/3f384240-2283-11e6-934d-f5ce6826371e.png)

Why is it doing this? I just want one copy of the file in the bundle.

I think this is a bug. A fellow dev pointed out that [in the webpack-dev-server code](https://github.com/webpack/webpack-dev-server/blob/a77eac516dace7f5072740206eda474a8141055b/bin/webpack-dev-server.js#L248), it explicitly duplicates the WDS runtime for each entry point. This should not happen. We should be able to have infinite entry points and only 1 WDS and HMR runtime in 1 of the bundles.

`npm uninstall compression-wepack-plugin` and if you have tried to use it, look in the `webpack.prod.js`. It is though not a dependency in the current `master` or pre-release.

I have found what the issue is and a work-around, but not a permanent fix.  The details are in the webpack issue below.  The work around is, on a Windows machine, make sure you use a capital letter for your drive letter when you cd to your project directory.  I.E.

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

Notice that I had to change to a different folder first, otherwise Windows does not change the case of the drive letter since it doesn't consider the directory to have changed.

The core issue is that __dirname is returning a value with an upper case drive letter but cwd() will return a lower case drive letter (unless you use the work around above). This needs to be fixed in nodejs.  Be sure and follow issue at the last link so the nodejs team will know.

I got this to work.

Replace: 

`filesGlob: [...]` and `exclude: [...]`

with

`"files": [ "src/main.ts", "typings/browser.d.ts", "node_modules/zone.js/dist/zone.js.d.ts", "./src/custom-typings.d.ts", "./typings/index.d.ts" ],`

(Typescript will throw an error if you have `filesGlob` or `exclude` with `files`).

Also make sure your dev server is running as well in a seperate process. Protractor isn't going to start your server for you, it's only going to access the localhost:3000 port.

See: 4f35422

I was able to get this working by renaming `filesGlob` to `files` and commenting out `exclude`, as pointed out above.
In order to get tests passing the app had to be running by first using `npm run start`. After that you can do  `npm run e2e` and all tests pass.

I needed to fully automate this for CI by calling a single npm script. Updating my npm e2e script to this solved it:
`"e2e": "(webdriver-manager start &) && sleep 2 && (npm run start . &) && npm run protractor"`

But for local development it could be a lot cleaner without the noise.

I have already fixed this [here](https://github.com/paynoattn/angular2-webpack-starter/commit/627ea042b8eced6c79c56f89376dd055fcc57ed2). I can create a pull request if this is approved.
I also removed dependencies not being used anywhere in the code, such as style-loader and several others. I can moved this into a seperate issue.
Somebody correct me if I'm wrong, but this is the attended behavior, you're supposed to build your code on your dev machine and only deploy the built version (So no need for those dependencies).

Sorry I'm new to this package so I'm not sure what the intention should be since it's not spelled out, I assumed that this package was meant for deployment automation, given many of the of the scripts steps in `package.json` such as `postinstall` and `build:prod` and `server:prod`.

IMHO the idea of 'build on your dev machine and only deploy the built version' is not good practice. The only way to deploy then is either use ftp/scp or something similar, or commit your `dist/` directory. I don't like either of those options.

In a node production environment everything could be automated by moving these dependencies, using git to checkout your latest code in production, and running your build and either `npm run server:prod` or adding a `server.js` and creating a simple express app that serves your `dist` folder.

On my side the deployment is still automated, I call the deployment, it builds everything and cause the upload via SSH of the dist/ resulted (and remotely call npm install). I think deployment is much lighter that way (which makes sense for production) as you move only a bunch of files instead of your whole source code (that is not going to be used anyway after the build) also, you cut global dependencies like Typescript.
You might as well not want your original source code to be uploaded to a production server.
Another argument would be that building your source code on the target server will make it busy for a much higher time, and will totally break things if the build fail (meanwhile if your local build fail, nothing gets uploaded).

I see your point about build failure but you're making a lot of assumptions about your ng2 app and your production environment. There are a number of use cases where you would want or need to build in production, such as if you are trying to integrate your ng2 app with a node app, or that the security team for your company has disabled ssh traffic in the network, or any other number of reasons.

We could argue all day which use case is more important/popular but since my changes don't effect your ability to deploy your way at all and gives others such as me the ability to build in production it seems kind of an irrelevant argument to have for me. 

The purpose of a starter is to help as many use cases as possible, not just yours. :D

I don't get your point @paynoattn, why in any way would you like to install 'building' dependencies in a production environment? Building is a oneshot action, and the libraries would remains useless after it.

If you would like to build on production environment:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

I don't get your point. If the intention is to not have unused build code in production then having dependencies seperated by devDependencies make no sense because none of this repository's node_modules will be used post-build, you should just remove your node_modules directory.

The point here is that if you want to build in production, via something like heroku, without having to do a manual deploy through the command line passing flags.
@paynoattn if you don't want to do a "manual deploy" then add an npm task to do it.

The devDependencies are exactly how they need to be. You don't deploy development builds to a production server. i.e there is no need for `webpack` to be in a deployment nor any of it's loaders.

It's JavaScript, which is served as static assets with something like `nginx` or using `angular universal` rendered on the server.

- **I'm submitting a ...**
  [X ] feature request
- **What is the current behavior?**

Currently Webpack HMR appends inlined style tags to the head in the form of <style></style> tags. This makes it difficult to view which component each css class belongs to, because the CSS inspector pane normally says "buttons.scss" when using <link href="button.css"> with sourcemaps.

Now it just says `<style>...</style>` in the right hand pane.

![no_inline_styles_please](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/13709948/15326836/4a919ee6-1c04-11e6-816f-d30e56658711.png)

When dealing with many css classes, its very difficult to know which component to go into to begin styling without it telling me which component's class is active.
- **What is the motivation / use case for changing the behavior?**

Here is what most CSS developers are used to and expect: 

![external_styles](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/13709948/15326901/80f21ace-1c04-11e6-9dd0-d0e5eff659fb.png)

It says frameworks-10c1164.css is the source of the class, therefore I know to go to that file/component to make changes. 

It would be ideal if webpack HMR preserved this standard CSS workflow while still enabling HMR. A simple solution is to simply appent external styles to the head such as <link href="buttons.scss"> and then swap out that <link> tag when HMR sends an update. 

Is it feasible?
I figured out how to do it. [My post here explains it](https://github.com/webpack/extract-text-webpack-plugin/issues/30#issuecomment-220724110).

Guys,
We love what you did and what you are doing.
But now I think it's time to ask himself the question:
Continue with webpack or switch to ng-cli with system.js?

Could someone please help me with some pros and cons of both solutions?

That's a hard one for now I think :p
Personally I'd stick with Webpack for a while longer

I think this actually helps settle some of the previous discussions about making this repo with less overhead, from what I've seen from using the cli it makes a pretty slim(comparatively) repo that is more tailored toward immediate, fast development. I think this repo can be more of an example app or teaching tool demonstrating different features like universal, css encapsulation, animations etc.
Eventually, this repo will turn into a few plugins for ng-cli. I'm still advocating webpack as it's faster to become production ready with code splitting and async loading than systemjs

in ng-conf pkozlowski invoked a new ng bundling reducing to less than 50k the bundle.js.
Also, I'm not sure new router will be compatible with webpack
The new router will be. Webpack is the way to go. Bundle size will be smaller with webpack 2
@gdi2290 Glad reading your last comment
All we are missing is a kinda yoeman templates.

I see the value of using the cli with Systemjs good for prototyping. In one or two lines, you already have a base Angular2 application. Yet, System.js is way more limited compared to Webpack and I would be careful to use System.js over Webpack for any big application.

On another hand, for knowing Webpack since now a few months, it's "sometimes" a pain to configure correctly, but this project helps a lot to get started with and I would highly recommend it for any medium/large project.

Also regarding the new router: I've started an Angular2 project few weeks ago based on this repo and then customized Webpack and all the rest to my needs. No problem getting the new router to work, you just need to follow the guide https://angular.io/docs/ts/latest/guide/router.html or anything similar. It's very little about Webpack actually, much more about Angular2 itself.

I personally think also that webpack for production apps is the way to go. there is definitely value in the CLI but I thik there is a lot to gain with webpack like was already mentioned here, good things land on webpack from all the communities not just Angular and that is a a benefit just on its own.

That being said I am sure that webpack will eventually be supported in the cli project as well. While that does not happen I would stick with an approach like this project.

Personally the current starter as is its of no use to me as a starting point because there is just way too many stuff on it, but I do pick up on great ideas here to create my own starters or adapt my projects. So thanks @gdi2290 and all the other guys contributing for the project;)
@gdi2290 Why don't you start an angular-cli addon using webpack now. I am sure lot of people will help to make webpack part of ng cli.

I have to agree with @joaogarin. The webpack approach seems to be more tailored towards building an production ready environment. For me webpack really offers everything i need for nearly every use case regarding web application development. Also don't forget that webpack 2 offers native support for loading es6 modules and even provides "tree-shaking" for creating even smaller builds. I doesn't know anything that systemjs can do, that webpack 2 doesn't.

But regarding Angular-CLI i have to say, that i like this approach for scaffolding web applications. Ember JS showed us how this needs to be done. So in my opinion a combination of angular cli and webpack would be the ultimate solution.

- **What kind of change does this PR introduce?** (Bug fix, feature, docs update, ...)

Update to conform to [Angular Style Guide](https://angular.io/styleguide)
- **What is the current behavior?** (You can also link to an open issue here)

some source files violate Coding Conventions rules on Import Destructuring Spacing (03-05) and Import Line Spacing (03-06)
- **What is the new behavior (if this is a feature change)?**

source conforms to style guide rules 03-05 and 03-06
- **Other information**:

Style 03-05: Import Destructuring Spacing
-Do leave one whitespace character inside of the import statements' curly braces when destructuring.
-Why? Whitespace makes it easier to read the imports.

Style 03-06: Import Line Spacing
-Do leave one empty line between third party imports and imports of code we created.
-Do list import lines alphabetized by the module.
-Do list destructured imported assets alphabetically.
-Why? The empty line makes it easy to read and locate imports.
-Why? Alphabetizing makes it easier to read and locate imports.

I have my stylesheets as SASS. Everything is working perfectly, but when I try to run karma tests it fails giving me an error `Module parse failed` and says `You may need an appropriate loader to handle this file type`.
I tried to install [karma-sass-preprocessor](https://www.npmjs.com/package/karma-sass-preprocessor) and[ karma-scss-preprocessor](https://www.npmjs.com/package/karma-scss-preprocessor) but nothing seems to work. What should I do?

I just ran into the same issue yesterday.

Adding in the code below in `webpack.test.js` worked for me.
`{ test: /\.scss$/, loader:'style!css!sass', exclude: [helpers.root('src/index.html')] },
`

Thanks. I used this code inside **webpack.common.js** and **webpack.test.js** in the "loaders: []" argument and it loads Scss perfectly.

well, I got it working. 

Using the universal-starter as an offset, I created a seperate webpack config for the server build. Important notes:

1) Dont use chunks (vendor/polyfills). Build everything as one entry.
2) In tsconfig.json, remove the "noEmitHelpers" entry, or you will get errors like

__declare is undefined.

3) merge the dependencies from universal-starter (package.json and typings.json)
4) Add seperate scripts to the package.json (copy the dev or test targets).

To run, you'd then have two terminals open, one doing "watch" to rebuild, and one running nodemon to run/restart the server 

I dont have the expertise to make it one single webpack config.

It seems to be another wrong decision of the angular team, and not the first.

I had a library of components developed following the oficial angular documentation based on SystemJs. It used "import javascript_file.js" to load external javascript files and worked. Tried to port to new webpack version and it doesnt work at all. Also, the size of the app loaded by the browser went from 2.7 MB to 3.3.

The last news I have are the new version jumps from 2 to 4. Angular project it's a chaos that seems to have lost the north. It is bloated and over engineering. I'm going to change to React.

it really seems that the angular2 team does not care about existing implementations using their framework. In my opinion Angular2 will be great one day but actually it is nearly unusable. Not at least because of the 3rd party libraries. I know, this is not their fault at all but they are changing their framework really often and they do not update the docs in time. Last week i did an update for several angular2 tools and nothing worked until i downgraded it again. 
SystemJS produces a lot of errors at my place while webpack seems to work as expected....mostly. 

But to be fair: The angular2 developers clearly say that this is still a very early version and its still beta. I think when they release the first stable version those errors will vanish....hopefully.

After a lot of investigation i managed to use webpack and systemjs at the same time. In my very personal opinion recompile each time with webpack during development time is clearly overkill. You should at least have the chance of using both and be able to switch without problems, but at first instance they are incompatible. Webpack sould be used for production.

I'm having a weird problem with npm install.

I have a project forked from this repo. A couple of weeks ago I did a regular merge with this repo.

Since then I have been unable to successfully run npm install. It fails at

`npm run typings -- install`

with the error:

`Unknown dependency: github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped/commit/31e6e105227e2e23686c3183bddf7c91f7f5b311`

The weird part is that if I clone my github copy of the fork it works. (My github copy of the fork is only a lightly modified fork of the original – I have another separate repo that has my working project) I spent most of yesterday trying to track down this issue. I have compared every file I think could possibly have a bearing on this – but all the config, typings and package files are identical between my working project and the repo that does work.

The last thing I did yesterday was to copy the package.json file to a new, empty directory and run `npm install` from this directory.

I get exactly the same error.

Has anyone got any ideas about what I might be doing wrong?

(Mac OS X, Node v6.0.0, npm 3.8.8)

TIA
Chris

Honestly, I worry about my own sanity sometimes.

The problem was staring me in the face all the time. It was a line I had added to my typings.json file some time back that I didn't need anymore. I really don't know why I didn't pick it up when I was comparing files.

I guess that's just something that happens to us all from time to time.

Thanks all.
